f.d: [18. de bzhin gshegs pa ri rab kyi rtse mor gshegs pa'i le'u]
BOOK THIRTEEN. Ascent to the Peak of Mount Sumeru
bam po nyi shu pa/

de nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus shar phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad dang / de bzhin du lho phyogs dang / nub phyogs dang / byang phyogs dang / byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams dang / shar lho'i phyogs mtshams dang / lho nub kyi phyogs mtshams dang / nub byang gi phyogs mtshams dang / 'og gi phyogs dang / steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gling bzhi pa 'di la sogs pa gling bzhi pa re re na yang de bzhin gshegs pa de dag de bzhin du bzhugs par snang ngo/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis chos ston cing / de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhabs kyi drung na 'khod par yang so so nas shes te/ bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang rdzu 'phrul mngon par 'du mdzad pa de ma btul bar byang chub kyi shing drung nas ri rab kyi rtse mo'i lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyi khang pa rnam par rgyal ba ga la ba der gshegs par snang ngo/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das gling bzhi pa 'di'i ri rab kyi rtse mar gshegs par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa dag gi ri rab kyi rtse mor gshegs par snang ste/ byin gyi rlabs snga ma dag kyang ma nyams par snang ngo/ / de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis bcom ldan 'das rnam par rgyal ba'i khang pa logs su mngon par gshegs pa rgyang ring po nas mthong nas rnam par rgyal ba'i khang pa'i nang du rings pa'i gzugs su rdzu 'phrul gyi rang bzhin seng+ge'i gdan phyogs rnam par snang ba'i snying po can/ bog re stong phrag bcus brgyan pa/ gser gyi dra ba stong phrag bcu kun tu bres pa/ gnam yol stong phrag bcus bla rer bres pa/ gdugs stong phrag bcu shin tu bzung ba/ dar gyi lda ldi stong phrag bcu rab tu dbyangs pa/ mu tig gi se mo do stong phrag bcus dga' dga' ltar byas pa/ gos stong phrag bcus mngon par bkab pa/ lha'i bu stong phrag bcus mdun du byas pa/ tshangs pa stong phrag bcus kun nas bskor ba/ 'od zer stong phrag bcus shin tu snang bar gyur pa bcom ldan 'das kyi gdan du bshams so/ / ji ltar gling bzhi pa 'di'i ri rab kyi rtse mor lha'i dbang po'i khang pa rnam par rgyal bar lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdan bshams pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi ri rab kyi rtse mo dag tu yang lha'i dbang po brgya byin dag gis de bzhin gshegs pa'i gdan dag tshul de 'dra ba dang / rgyan de 'dra bar bshams par gyur to/ /

THEN, BY THE SPIRITUAL POWER of the Enlightened One, in the Jambudvipa continent of all worlds in the ten directions there was seen the Enlightened One sitting under a tree, in each place with enlightening beings receiving the Buddha’s spiritual power and expounding the teaching, all thinking they were at all times facing the Buddha in person. At that time the Buddha, without leaving the foot of the enlightenment tree, ascended Mount Sumeru and headed for the palace of Indra; then Indra, king of gods, in front of the Hall of Surpassing Wonder, seeing Buddha coming from afar, adorned this palace by means of his supernatural power. He put in it a lion throne of banks of radiant lights, all made of exquisite jewels, with ten thousand levels of dazzling ornaments and ten thousand nets of gold covering it, ten thousand kinds of curtains and ten thousand levels of canopies arrayed all around, with ten thousand embroidered silks as curtain sashes, ten thousand strings of pearls joined together, and ten thousand robes spread on the throne. Ten thousand godlings and ten thousand Brahma kings surrounded it in front and behind, while ten thousand light beams illumined it.

de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis bcom ldan 'das kyi gdan seng+ge'i khri bcas nas rje sa dang rim gro chen pos bcom ldan 'das gang na ba der thal mo sbyar te phyag 'tshal nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das/ gshegs su gsol/ bde bar gshegs pa/ gshegs su gsol/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bde bar gshegs sam zhes gsol to/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis spyan drangs nas rnam par rgyal ba'i khang par gshegs so/ / de ltar bcom ldan 'das gshegs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi lha'i khang pa dag tu'ang gshegs par snang ngo/ / de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis sangs rgyas kyi mthus sum cu rtsa gsum gyi khang pa thams cad du glu dang / rol mo dang / sil snyan brgya phrag mang po dag btang ste zhi bar byas nas yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas snga ma dag las dge ba'i rtsa ba skyed pa de dag rjes su dran nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /

Then Indra, having set up this throne for the Enlightened One, bowed and joined his palms, reverently facing the Buddha, and said, “Welcome, World Honored One; welcome, Blissful One; welcome, Realized One, Perfectly Enlightened One: please be so compassionate as to sojourn in this palace.” Then the Buddha, accepting his invitation, entered the Hall of Surpassing Wonder. This also took place in the same way in all the worlds of the ten directions. Then, due to the Buddha’s spiritual power, all the music in the palaces spontaneously ceased, and Indra recalled to himself how he had planted roots of goodness with Buddhas of the past; he spoke in verse, saying,

bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / thugs rje chen po mnga' ba 'od srung rigs skyes pa/ / rnam par rgyal bar gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / gser thub bsgribs pa med par rab tu gzigs pa de/ / rin chen sna tshogs gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / bsod skyabs gser gyi ri bo 'bar ba 'dra ba de/ / rtse mo mchog tu gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / thams cad mnga' ba dgra bcom dri ma gsum sel ba/ / mdzod spu'i rtse mor gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / sangs rgyas gtsug tor dgongs pa zil gyis mi non pa/ / rin chen sna tshogs gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / rnam par gzigs pa skyes bu'i zla ba mi yi mgon/ / rin chen rgyan du gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / shin tu rgyas pa don dam mkhas shing bstan pa de/ / ma la ya yi rtse mor gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / sangs rgyas ston mchog thogs pa mi mnga' ba/ / dri med zla bar gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / grags pa dri ma med pa mgon po pad+mo'i bla/ / dri ma med par gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / mgon po mar me mdzad pa 'od snang mnga' ba de/ / 'od zer dra bar gshegs gyur pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /

Kashyapa Buddha had great compassion, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Kanakamuni’s vision was unobstructd, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Krakucchanda was like a mountain of gold, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Vishvabhu Buddha was undefiled, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Shikhin Buddha was free from discrimination, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Vipashin Buddha was like a full moon, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Pushya clearly realized the ultimate truth, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Tishya Buddha’s eloquence was unhindered, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Padma Buddha was utterly pure, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.
Dipankara Buddha was effulgent, Supreme among the auspicious. That Buddha has come into this palace, Hence this place is most auspicious.

ji ltar lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis sangs rgyas kyi mthus yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bcu'i rgyal ba gshegs pa glur blangs te tshigs su bcad pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na yang sangs rgyas kyi mthus lha'i dbang po rnams de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan gzhan dang gzhan gyis yang dag pa'i rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bcu'i rgyal ba gshegs pa dag glur len cing tshigs su bcad par gyur to/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das rnam par rgyal ba'i khang par gshegs nas skyil mo krung bcas te bzhugs so; ; bcom ldan 'das ji ltar bzhugs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na yang de bzhin gshegs pa dag gdan de dag la bzhugs par snang ngo/ / bcom ldan 'das de ltar bzhugs ma thag tu de'i tshe sangs rgyas kyi mthus rnam par rgyal ba'i khang pa de yang sum cu rtsa gsum thams cad kyi khang pa dang / lha'i ris tsam du che bar snang bar gyur te/ 'di na ji lta ba ltar 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na yang de bzhin no/ /

As in this world the king of the thirty-threefold heaven, Indra, by the spiritual power of the Buddha, extolled the virtues of ten Buddhas, so did all the Indras in the worlds of the ten directions also praise the Buddhas’ virtues. Then the World Honored One entered the Hall of Surpassing Wonder and sat crosslegged: this hall suddenly became vastly spacious, like the dwelling places of all the celestial hosts. The same thing happened in all worlds in the ten directions.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las; de bzhin gshegs pa ri rab kyi rtse mor gshegs pa'i le'u ste/ bco brgyad pa'o// //
[19. ri rab kyi rtse mor de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs kyi tshigs su bcad pa'i le'u]
BOOK FOURTEEN. Eulogies on Mount Sumeru

de nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ongs par gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag so so nas 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi pha rol nas 'ongs pa sha stag ste; byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing yang byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar chos kyi blo gros dang / thams cad blo gros dang / dpal gyi blo gros dang / yon tan blo gros dang / brtson 'grus blo gros dang / dge ba'i blo gros dang / ye shes blo gros dang / bden pa'i blo gros dang / mchog gi blo gros dang / dam pa'i blo gros dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar dbang po'i me tog dang / pad+mo'i me tog dang / rin po che'i me tog dang / ut+pa la'i me tog dang / rdo rje'i me tog dang / spos kyi me tog dang / yid du 'ong ba'i me tog dang / 'od zer gyi me tog dang / ldum bu'i me tog dang / nam mkha'i me tog dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs par spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar zla ba gzhan ma yin pa dang / zla ba ma mnyam pa dang / zla ba mi g.yo ba dang / zla ba mi sgul ba dang / zla ba chu'i lha dang / zla ba thogs pa med pa dang / zla ba'i 'od zer dang / zla ba rdul med pa dang / zla ba rnams par grub pa dag go/

THEN, DUE TO THE SPIRITUAL POWER of the Buddha, there came and gathered great enlightening beings from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in a buddha-land, coming from worlds far away, beyond lands as numerous as atoms in a hundred buddha-lands. Their names were Wisdom of Truth, Total Wisdom, Supreme Wisdom, Virtuous Wisdom, Vigorous Wisdom, Good Wisdom, Knowing Wisdom, True Wisdom, Unexcelled Wisdom, and Stable Wisdom. The worlds they came from were called Indra Flower, Red Lotus, Jewel Flower, Blue Lotus, Diamond Flower, Fragrant Flower, Delightful Flower, Rosy Dawn Flower, Adorning Flower, and Space Flower. They had each cultivated pure practice with Buddhas; the Buddhas were called Extraordinary Moon, Infinite Moon, Imperturbable Moon, Wind Moon, Water Moon, Liberation Moon, Unexcelled Moon, Constellation Moon, Pure Moon, Comprehending Moon.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyis bcom ldan 'das la phyag 'tshal te sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rgyas par bkang nas gang nas 'ongs pa'i phyogs su brten te/ seng+ge'i khri rnam par snang ba'i snying po can dag mngon par sprul nas skyil mo krung bcas te 'khod do/ / ji ltar 'jig rten gyi khams 'di'i ri rab kyi rtse mo la byang chub sems dpa' rnams lhags pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa thams cad dang / lha'i dbang po'i khang pa kun na yang de bzhin te/ byang chub sems dpa' ming de skad ces bya ba sha stag go /'jig rten gyi khams kyang de skad ces bya ba nas 'ongs pa sha stag go /de bzhin gshegs pa yang mtshan de skad ces bya ba'i zham ring na tshangs par spyod par sha stag go /

When the enlightening beings had reached the Buddha, they prostrated themselves at the Buddha’s feet, and then magically produced luminous lion seats in the direction from which they had come. In the same way as the enlightening beings gathered atop Mount Sumeru in this world, so it was in all worlds; their names, worlds, and the names of their Buddhas were all like this.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis zhabs kyi mtho bong gnyis nas 'od zer bye ba phrag stong pa kye ste/ phyogs bcu thams cad snang bar byas nas 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyang bstan to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyis kyang 'jig rten gyi khams de dag thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa thams cad dang / ri rab kyi rtse mo thams cad de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa yod pa thams cad kyang mthong bar gyur to/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di skad smras so/ /

At that juncture the Buddha emitted a hundred thousand billion light beams of sublime hue from the toes of his feet, illumining all the worlds in the ten directions, so that the Buddhas and congregations in the palaces of the Indras atop Mt. Sumerus were all revealed. Then the enlightening being Wisdom of Truth, infused with spiritual power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

snang ba dri ma med la ltos/ / ri rab rtse mo thams cad la/ / mgon po dag ni rab tu snang / / rnam par rgyal ba kun na bzhugs/ /
lha'i rgyal po thams cad kyis/ / spyan drangs shing ni gshegs par gyur/ / kun kyang sangs rgyas bcu dag gis/ / rab tu gshegs pas mngon par bstod/ /
kun gyi 'khor kyang gcig pa ste/ / byang chub sems dpa' mang po lhags/ / phyogs bcu dag nas 'ongs gyur cing / / yid du 'ong ba'i stan la 'khod/ /
kun gyi ming yang 'di nyid de/ / ji ltar nged la btags pa bzhin/ / 'jig rten khams kyi ming dag kyang / / de skad dag nas kun kyang 'ongs/ /
'jig rten khams rnams thams cad na/ / drang srong chen po'i mtshan kyang de/ / de na tshangs spyod bla med la/ / the tshom med par de dag spyod/ /
kye ma rgyal sras khyed ltos shig / drang srong chen po'i byin rlabs kyis/ / 'dzam bu'i gling rnams thams cad na; ; rgyal ba 'di na bzhugs snyam byed/ /
bdag cag rnams ni 'di snyam du/ / ri rab rtse la bde gshegs snyam/ / 'jig rten khams rnams kun na yang / / sangs rgyas ngo mtshar rmad re che; ;
'jig rten khams rnams thams cad na/ / byang chub mchog tu sems btang zhing / / de dag smon lam 'di btab ste/ / byang chub spyod pa rab tu spyod/ /
kha dog mdog ni tshad med pas/ / gang zag mchog ni spyod byed kyang / / chos kyi dbyings la mi chags te/ / de dag sus kyang mi shes so/ /
gang gis 'jig rten mun bsal cing / / thams cad dus su rnam snang ba/ / de la 'dra ba gang yang med/ / de ni shes par ji ltar rung / /

Buddha emits a pure light Showing all the Guides of the worlds Sojourning in the Halls of Wonder On the peaks of Mt. Sumerus.
All of the kings of gods Invited the Buddhas into the palace, All with ten beautiful verses Praising the enlightened ones.
Among those great assemblies The groups of enlightening beings Have come from the ten directions And sit calmly on the seats they made.
The enlightening beings in those congregations All have the same names as we And the names of the lands they come from Are also the same as ours.
The Buddhas of their own lands Also have the same names as ours; Each one has, with a Buddha, Purely cultivated unexcelled practices.
Buddha-children, you should observe The Buddha’s power of freedom: In all the Jambudvipas All think the Buddha’s there.
We now see the Buddha On top of Sumeru: It’s the same in the ten directions, By the Buddha’s power of freedom.
In each world They determine to seek the Buddha-way, And based on such a vow Practice enlightening deeds.
Buddha, with various bodies, Travels throughout the worlds, Unhindered in the cosmos, Beyond the ken of anyone.
The light of his wisdom always shines everywhere, Removing all the darkness of the world; It has no compare at all: How can it be comprehended?
de nas byang chub sems dpa' thams cad blo gros kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Total Wisdom, infused with the power of the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

'dren pa rnams ni mthong nas kyang / / bskal pa mang po 'das gyur te/ / 'jig rten mgon skyob de dag gi / chos nyid de ni shes pa min/ /
mtshan ma dag la spyod pa rnams/ / gti mug dra ba 'phel bar gyur/ / sangs rgyas gang gis ma mthong ba/ / 'khor ba'i btson rar ldongs pa yin/ /
chos rnams 'di dag brtags byas na/ / rang bzhin shes par mi rung ste/ / skye dang shi 'phor gyur pa rnams/ / ming tsam du ni bstan pa yin/ /
chos rnams gang yang 'pho ba med/ / gang yang de bzhin skye ba med/ / chos nyid 'di ni shes gyur na/ / sangs rgyas kun na rab tu snang / /
gzung du med cing bltar med cing / / chos kyi rnams ni rang bzhin med/ / dngos med pa yi mtha' shes na/ / sangs rgyas rnams la tshang kyang med/ /
tshad med pa yi chos rnams kyi/ / rang bzhin gang gis yongs shes pa/ / des ni ci zhig yod ces par/ / mthong bar 'gyur ba gang yang med/ /
gang rnams mtshan ma'i rjes 'brang ba/ / de dag byis pa'i chos nyid de/ / de phyir mtshan nyid kun med pa'i/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyang mi mthong ngo/ /
dus gsum byung ba'i thub pa rnams/ / mtshan rab kun dang ldan pa ste/ / mi gnas tshul du bzhugs pa yin; ; chos kyi dbyings la g.yo ba med/ /
la la dag gi chos nyid shes/ / la la dag ni chos kyang brjod/ / gang la the tshom mi mnga' ba'i/ / yang dag sangs rgyas de ring mthong / /
sangs rgyas rnams kyis chos nyid 'di/ / chos kyi blo gros 'dis brjod do/ / de thos nas kyang bdag gis ni/ / sangs rgyas byang chub bsam yas shes/ /

Even if one always looked at Buddha For a hundred thousand eons, Not according to the absolute truth But looking at the savior of the world,
Such a person is grasping appearances And increasing the web of ignorance and delusion, Bound in the prison of birth and death, Blind, unable to see the Buddha.
Observing all things To be without inherent existence, Whatever their appearances of origin and disappearance, Being just provisional descriptions,
All things are unborn, All things are imperishable: To one who can understand this The Buddha will always be manifest.
The nature of things is fundamentally empty and null, With no grasping and no vision. The emptiness of inherent nature is Buddha; It cannot be assessed in thought.
If one knows the inherent nature Of all things is like this, This person will not be affected By any afflictions.
Ordinary people seeing things Just pursue the forms And don’t realize things are formless: Because of this they don’t see Buddha.
The Sage is detached from the realms of time, Replete with the marks of greatness, Dwelling in nondwelling, Omnipresent without moving.
I observe all things And clearly understand them; Now I see the Buddha With certainty, free from doubt.
Wisdom of Truth has already explained The real nature of the Enlightened; From him I have understood That enlightenment’s inconceivable.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dpal gyi blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Supreme Wisdom, receiving power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

kye ma sangs rgyas dpal mnga' ba'i/ / ye shes shes rab shin tu che/ / de la 'jig rten shin tu rmongs/ / sangs rgyas chos ni bsam mi khyab/ /
tshul bzhin ma yin 'du shes kyis/ / byis pa rnams ni sems byed pas/ / de phyir 'du shes kun sbyangs pa'i/ / sangs rgyas rnams ni mi mthong ngo/ /
shes rab chung ba thams cad ni/ / phung po'i 'du shes rnams la gnas/ / phung po rnam par ma bsgoms pas/ / de bzhin gshegs pa mi mthong ngo/ /
dngos med dngos su bshad pa ni/ / bdag gi dngos zhes bya ba yin/ / chos rnams thams cad shes bgyis shing / / rgyal ba rnam par snang mdzad ltos/ /
sngon chad phung po'i tshul bzhin du/ / ma 'ongs rnams kyang sus mthong ba/ / ma 'ongs pa yi tshul shes pas/ / sangs rgyas bsam gyis mi khyab ltos/ /
ji ltar snang ba med pa yi/ / mun pa'i nang na gzugs mi snang / / de bzhin chos rnams bshad pa ni/ / mkhas kyang shes par mi rung ngo/ /
ji ltar dri ma ldan mig gis/ / gsal ba'i gzugs kyang mi mthong ngo/ / de bzhin sems ni ma sbyangs pas/ / sangs rgyas chos ni mi mthong ngo/ /
ji ltar nyi ma bsgribs med pa/ / rab rib can gyis mi mthong ba/ / de bzhin phug na gnas sems kyis; ; sangs rgyas dag ni mi mthong ngo/ /
de bas mig ni rnam par sbyongs/ / gzugs kyi 'du shes rnam par sgoms/ / chos rnams mthong ba med pa yis/ / 'od mdzad rab tu mthong ma yin/ /
ji ltar sngon blos kun bshad cing / / bdag gis ji ltar thos pa bzhin/ / sangs rgyas byang chub mi rnyings pa/ / rnam par snang mdzad rab tu mthong / /

The Enlightened One’s great wisdom Is rare, beyond compare; All beings in the worlds Cannot reach it in their thoughts.
Ordinary people’s deluded views Grasp forms and are not veritable. Buddha is beyond all forms, So not within their view.
The deluded and unknowing Wrongly grasp the forms of the five clusters, Not understanding their true nature; Such people don’t see Buddha.
Knowing that all things Have no inherent being of their own, Understanding the nature of things this way One will see Vairocana.
Caused by the preceding five clusters, Succeeding clusters arise in continuum; Comprehending this nature, One sees Buddha, inconceivable.
Just like a jewel in the dark Cannot be seen if there is no lamp, With no one to explain Buddha’s teaching Even the intelligent cannot comprehend it.
And like an eye with cataracts Cannot see pure beautiful colors, So too the impure mind Cannot see the Buddha’s teaching.
And as the bright clear sun Cannot be seen by the blind, Those who have no wisdom Can never see the Buddhas.
If one can remove the eye’s cataracts And abandon the concept of form And not see in terms of things, Then one can see the Buddha.
Total Wisdom has explained The enlightenment of the Buddhas; I, having learned from him, Have gotten to see Vairocana.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' yon tan blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyis mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Virtuous Wisdom, imbued with power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

gnas med pa yi chos rnams la/ / gnas ni yongs su brtags pas na/ / de phyir srid pa'i brtson ra na/ / byis pa rnams ni rab tu 'khor/ /
brjod pas brjod du mi rung chos/ / zlo zhan rnams kyis rnam par brtags/ / des ni yongs su bsgribs byas pas/ / bdag gi sems kyang rab rmongs byed/ /
shes rab chung la lam nor cing / / bdag gi sems la mi mkhas pa/ / phyin ci log gi blo dag gis/ / mi bzad lus ni 'phel bar byed/ /
gang gis stong pa ma mthong ba/ / de dag 'khor zhing nyam yang nga/ / chos mig bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i/ / mig kyang de la yod pa min/ /
de bas mig ni sbyang bar gyis/ / bsam pa rnams kyang rnam par sems/ / gang phyir bdag cag sngon chad du/ / bde gshegs ma mthong chud kyang zos/ /
yang dag sangs rgyas mthong ba na'ang / / gang gi sems la chags med pa/ / des ni sangs rgyas cis byung ba'i/ / chos rnams de dag rab tu mthong / /
gang gis shes rab che mnga' ba/ / chos su bde gshegs mthong ba rnams/ / de dag 'jig rten mig can te/ / gang gis mthong ba mthong zhes bya/ /
lhag mthong med par mthong ba ni/ / chos rnams ngan par mthong ba ste/ / lhag mthong gis ni mthong gyur na/ / thams cad mthong ba med pa yin/ /
kye ma chos kyi chos nyid ni/ / yang dag sangs rgyas rnams kyis bshad/ / de ni rang bzhin thams cad du/ / shi ba med cing 'tsho ba med/ /
sangs rgyas byang chub ji 'dra ba; ; dpal gyi blos ni sngon bstan te/ / de las bdag gis thos nas kyang / / sangs rgyas chos nyid shes ma gyur/ /

Things have no true reality; Because of wrongly grasping them as real Do ordinary people therefore Revolve in the prison of birth and death.
Things expressed by words Those of lesser wisdom wrongly discriminate And therefore create barriers And don’t comprehend their own minds.
If one doesn’t comprehend one’s own mind, How can one know the right path? Based on misconstrued intellect They increase all evils.
Not seeing all things are empty, Always suffering the pains of birth and death, This is because such people Cannot yet have the pure objective eye.
In the past I experienced suffering Because I didn’t see Buddha. So one should clarify the eye of reality And see what is to be seen.
If one can see the Buddha, One’s mind will have no grasping; Such a person can then perceive Truth as the Buddha knows it.
If one can see Buddha’s real teaching, One is said to have great knowledge; This person has pure eyes And can see into the world.
No view is seeing Which can see all things; If one has any views about things, This is not seeing anything.
The nature of all things Has no origin and no end. How wonderful the Great Guide: Awakened himself, he can awaken others.
Supreme Wisdom has explained The truth realized by the Buddhas; We, having learned from him, Can know the Buddha’s true nature.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus blo gros kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Vigorous Wisdom, receiving power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

rnam par rtog pa spyod pa yi/ / mig ni shin tu 'khrul pa yin/ / 'khrul par mthong ba log pa ste/ / sangs rgyas la ni log mi mnga'/ /
gang gis log par shes gyur te/ / yang dag ji bzhin ma nor la/ / yang dag ma yin bden shes na/ / sangs rgyas dri med mthong ba yin/ /
mthong ba dag gis dri mar 'gyur/ / rnam par mthong na de med de/ / sangs rgyas rnams ni mthong dang bral/ / de bas rnam par gzigs zhes bya/ /
de ni 'jig rten spyod pa ste/ / 'jig rten de yang rnam par brtags/ / 'jig rten 'jig pa shes gyur na/ / snang ba dag ni skye bar 'gyur/ /
'jig rten rnams kyi snang pa ni/ / 'jig rten mtshan nyid snang ba ste/ / yang dag ji bzhin bsam byas shing / / de ltar mthong na mthong ba'o/ /
de ltar mthong na nyon mongs med/ / dbang du gyur cing zag pa med/ / gang gis tha dad med mthong ba/ / dngos por brtags pa ma yin no/ /
rtog dang rnam par rtog pa ni/ / sangs rgyas chos rnams brjod pa ste/ / de dag yod pa ma yin pas/ / rang bzhin de phyir sbyangs pa yin/ /
de dag rang bzhin rnam par dag / nam mkha' bzhin du mtshan nyid med/ / de dag la ni ston pa med/ / mkhas pa rnams kyis de ltar ltos/ /
chos rnams la ni mos med de/ / chos kyi 'du shes rnams bsgoms shing / / shes pa de yang ma bsgoms pa/ / des ni thub chen mthong ba yin/ /
ji ltar yon tan blos brjod pa/ / de ltar yang dag sangs rgyas mthong / / de mthong bas na 'du byed kun/ / rang bzhin gyis ni rnam par zhi/ /

If one dwells on discrimination, One ruins the eye of purity; Ignorant, false views increase, And one never sees the Buddha.
If one can understand falsehood As it is, without delusion, And know the basis of delusion is itself reality, One’s perception of Buddha will be pure.
If there are views, this is defilement; This is not yet to be considered seeing. By dismissing all views Can one thus see Buddha.
Things spoken of in conventional terms People wrongly conceptualize; Knowing the world is all birthless: This is seeing the world.
If one sees seeing the world, This seeing is a feature of the world; In reality they’re equal, no different: This is called true insight.
If one sees they’re equal, no different, One won’t discriminate among things. Such vision is free from delusions: Without indulgence, it’s free.
All the different things Pointed out by the Buddhas Are impossible to apprehend Because their nature’s pure.
The nature of things is fundamentally pure; Like space, it has no marks. Nothing at all can explain it: This do the wise observe.
Divorcing the concept of things, Not indulging in anything, And not even cultivating this, One can see the great Sage.
As Virtuous Wisdom explained, This is called one who sees Buddha; All the actions there be Are all inherently nil.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Good Wisdom, infused with Buddha’s power, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

kye ma sangs rgyas dpa' chen rnams/ / de bzhin gshegs pa tshad med do/ / rnam grol thugs ni sdig mi mnga'/ / 'jig rten mthar phyin rgal ba'o/ /
yang dag ji bzhin ma nor bar/ / bskal pa rnams ni tshad med pas/ / ji ltar mkhas pas mthong ba bzhin/ / 'jig rten sgron mas rab tu gzigs/ /
'du byed thams cad skad cig ma/ / so so'i skye bo de dag 'gengs/ / nam mkha'i khams ni bzung byas shing / / de dag de phyir khom pa med/ /
khom pa med ces bya ba ni/ / ci yang brjod du med pa ste/ / khom pa med pa'i rang bzhin gyis/ / khom pa bsam gyis mi khyab thob/ /
gang la dngos po med pa yi/ / mi zad khom pa med par bshad/ / yod pa'i rang bzhin shes gyur na/ / des ni grags chen mthong ba yin/ /
mthong ba med pa mthong zhes bya/ / yod pa med pa'ang yod ces bya/ / mthong ba dag gam yod pa min/ / ma bsgoms pa ni rnam par bsgoms/ /
ji ltar blta ba sus mthong ba/ / de dag gis ni lta ba bshig / gang la sangs rgyas smos pa yi/ / de dag chos rnams zhig pa med/ /
ji ltar thub pas bstan pa bzhin/ / sangs rgyas yongs su sus mthong ba/ / de ni 'jig rten snang bar byed/ / rgyal ba rnam par snang mdzad bzhin/ /
chos rnams kyi ni snang ba gcig / de bzhin gshegs pas rab tu bstan/ / des ni brtson blo brtan pa de/ / chos mang bye ba rab tu ston/ /
yod dang med pa shes byas te; ; gang gi 'du shes rnam bsgoms pa/ / des ni sangs rgyas mthong ba ste/ / yang dag mtha' la rab tu gnas/ /

Extraordinary, the great beings, The countless enlightened ones Are free from taint, their minds are free; Self-liberated, they can liberate others.
I see the Lamps of the Worlds As they are, without delusion, As one who has accumulated knowledge Over eons can see.
The acts of ordinary people All soon pass away; Their nature is like space, So said to be without end.
When the wise speak of endlessness, This is still not saying anything; Because inherent nature is endless, It can have an inconceivable end.
In the endlessness spoken of There are no beings to be found; Knowing the nature of things is thus, One will see the Honored One.
No view is called seeing, The birthless is called beings; Whether views or beings, Knowing they’ve no substantial nature,
The seer dismisses entirely The subject and object of seeing; Not destroying reality, This person knows the Buddha.
If one knows the Buddha And the truth the Buddha tells, One can illumine the world Like Buddha Vairocana does.
The truly enlightened point out well The pure road of one truth; The great being Vigorous Wisdom Expounds innumerable teachings:
Whether of existence or nonexistence, His conceptions are all removed: Thus he can see the Buddha And abide in reality.
de na byang chub sems dpa' ye shes blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Knowing Wisdom, imbued with power from the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

rgyal ba'i bstan pa 'di thos pas/ / snang ba bdag cag shes par gyur; ; phyogs bcu kun tu snang ba yi/ / yang dag sangs rgyas des kyang mthong / /
sems can rang bzhin yod gyur pa/ / de ni sems can g.yang sa ste/ / 'di la ci yang yod pa min/ / tshig gi lam rnams bsdus pa 'o/ /
byis pa 'dzin dang bcas pa rnams/ / bdag lus yang dag 'dzin pa la/ / sangs rgyas snang bar mi 'gyur te/ / de bzhin gshegs pa gzung ba med/ /
yang dag sangs rgyas ma mthong zhing / / gang rnams mig yod ma yin pa/ / de skad bskal pa grangs med du/ / srid pa'i gang chen mtsho na 'khor/ /
nyon mongs can ni 'khor bar bshad/ / nyon mongs med pa mya ngan 'das/ / mya ngan 'das dang 'khor ba yang / / rang bzhin rnyed par mi rung ngo/ /
'khor zhes bya ba brda yin te/ / mya ngan 'das pa brjod pa yin/ / 'phags pa'i chos rnams ma skyes pa/ / bla ma dag ni mi shes so/ /
'di ni sangs rgyas rgyal ba 'di/ / 'di yin 'di 'dra'i 'du shes can/ / de dag sangs rgyas mi mthong ste/ / tshul bzhin ma yin phyin ci log /
zhi ba'i rang bzhin ji lta bar/ / gang gis zhi ba shes gyur pa/ / des ni tshig gi lam 'das pa'i/ / yang dag sangs rgyas rab tu mthong / /
chos rnams kun gyi spyod pa ni/ / rab tu brjod kyang bstan pa med/ / 'on kyang mnyam pa nyid du blta/ / rgyal ba chos rnams kun dang mnyam/ /
yang dag sangs rgyas mtha' dbus med/ / thog ma dag dang tha mar yang / / 'gal med rtsa ba med pas na/ / de ni sangs rgyas de phyir brjod/ /

Hearing the supreme teaching, I produce the light of wisdom Illumining all worlds everywhere, Seeing all the Buddhas.
Herein there’s not the slightest thing: Only provisional names; Those who think there’s self and person Enter a dangerous path due to this.
People who grasp and cling Think the body really exists: The Buddha is not something grasped, So they never get to see.
These people lack the eye of wisdom And cannot see the Buddha, Circulating in the sea of birth and death Through uncountable eons.
Contention is called birth-and-death, Noncontention is nirvana: Birth-and-death and nirvana Both cannot be grasped.
If one pursues provisional names And grasp these two things One is not in accord with reality And doesn’t know the Sage’s subtle path.
If one produces such conceptions— “This is Buddha, this is supreme”— One is deluded—this is not real truth; Thus one cannot see true awakening.
If one can know this real body’s Quiescent character of true thusness, One can see the truly enlightened Transcending the path of speech.
Things expressed in words Cannot disclose the character of reality; Only through equanimity can one see Things, including the Buddha.
The Truly Enlightened in the past The future, and the present, Forever sever the root of discriminiation— That’s why they’re called Buddha.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' bden pa'i blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshi tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being True Wisdom, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse.

sangs rgyas rnams ni mnyam pa'i phyir/ / bskal pa bsam gyis mi khyab par/ / sems can dmyal bar gnas kyang bla/ / de ni bde ba bsam mi khyab; ;
ci phyir zhe na bskal pa rnams/ / grangs med sdug bsngal sngon chad byung / / 'on kyang bde gshegs ma thos pas/ / bdag cag 'khor las ma grol lo/ /
de bzhin ma nor chos kyi rnams/ / yang dag nyid du rtogs gyur te/ / gang la 'grogs pa med pa rnams/ / de dag byang chub bla na med/ /
sangs rgyas rnams dang mngon sum pa/ / sngon chad ma byung 'byung mi 'gyur; ; gang phyir sangs rgyas brjod pa'i chos/ / de dag mtshan nyid med pa 'o/ /
chos rnams blta dka' ji bzhin du/ / gang zhig de ltar rtog pa ni/ / de dag sangs rgyas kun gzigs pa; ; yang dag lta bas shin tu mthong / /
yang dag la ni yang dag gzigs/ / yang dag min par yang dag min/ / 'di yi mtha' ni ston pas na/ / sangs rgyas sangs rgyas zhes kyang bya/ /
khor du ma chud chos bstan te/ / sangs rgyas chos rnams rab tu brjod/ / 'di ni sangs rgyas sgom pa ste/ / gcig tu dmigs pa ma yin no/ /
de ltar mang dang gcig gnas pa/ / mang po dag tu rnam par shes/ / gnas pa med pa'i chos rnams kyis/ / bsags pa dag kyang rab tu byas/ /
byas pa med cing byed pa med/ / las kyi 'du shes rnam bsgoms shing / / las 'di ji bzhin shes byas nas/ / rnam pa dag kyang mi dmigs so/ /
gang la sangs rgyas bzhugs pa yi/ / nges pa'i gnas ni dmigs med pas/ / gnas pa med pa'i chos rnams kyis/ / sangs rgyas g.yo ba gang yang med/ /

I’d rather suffer the pains of hell While able to hear the name of Buddha Than to experience boundless pleasure Without hearing the name of Buddha.
The reason for suffering in the past Over countless eons Revolving within birth and death Is due to not hearing the name of Buddha.
Not deluded about things, Realizing them as they truly are, Detached from all compounded forms: This is called unsurpassed awakening.
The present is not compounded, Nor are the past and future; All things have no signs: This is the real body of Buddha.
If one can see this way The profound truth of things, Then one can see all Buddhas’ Reality-body in its true aspect.
Seeing what’s true as true And what’s not true as untrue: Such ultimate understanding Is the reason for the name of Buddha.
Buddha’s truth cannot be perceived; Realizing this is called perceiving truth. The Buddhas practice this way: Nothing can be grasped.
Knowing they are many because one And one because many, Realize all things have no basis And only arise from compounding.
There is no creator or created: They only arise from habitual conceptions. How can we know it is so? Because other than this naught is.
All things have no abode: No definite locus can be found; The Buddhas abide in this, Ultimately unwavering.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' mchog gi blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Unexcelled Wisdom, receiving Buddha’s power, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

sems can chen po bla na med/ / sems can 'du shes rnam par bsgoms/ / 'jug par bya ba gang yang med/ / de bas bla na med ces bya/ /
gang la phra ba yod min pa/ / de la sbom pa'ang yod pa min/ / de ni sangs rgyas rnams kyis brnyes/ / rnam par mi rtog 'dus ma byas/ /
gang zhig sangs rgyas spyod yul ba/ / de la phra ba yod pa min/ / yang dag sangs rgyas bgrang dang bral/ / de ni sangs rgyas chos nyid do/ /
mun pa rnams ni rnam gsal cing / / de bzhin gshegs pa rnam par snang / / de la snang ba gang yang med/ / mi snang ba yang ci yang med/ /
thams cad chos la kun nas dga'/ / skyes pa med cing gnas pa med/ / 'dod chags med cing rten pa med/ / chos nyid de yang sbed pa med/ /
gang la gnyis su bgrang med cing / / gcig kyang yod pa ma yin pas/ / ji bzhin rab tu gnas pa yi/ / shes rab chen po legs par mthong / /
mi gnyis pa la gnyis pa med/ / gnyis pa med pa stong pa ste/ / stong pa de yang khams gsum kun/ / de ni sangs rgyas mthong ba'o/ /
byis pas byang chub mi shes kyang / / de dag de la rab tu gnas/ / gnas pa med pa'i chos rnams kyis/ / rang gi lus ni rjes su blta/ /
lus med pa ni lus su bshad/ / 'byung ba med cing bstan du med/ / 'jig tshogs mang po bltar med pa/ / sangs rgyas sku ni bla na med/ /
sangs rgyas chos kyi rang bzhin nyid/ / de skad bden pa'i blos smras te/ / de thos pas ni mig kyang sbyangs/ / shin tu 'od kyang dang zhing snang / /

The unexcelled great beings Dismiss the concept of creatures. None can surpasss them, That’s why they’re called unexcelled.
The sphere attained by the Buddhas Has no fabrication and no discrimination; The gross has no existence, And neither does the fine.
The realms accessible to Buddhas Are innumerable therein; True awareness is detached from numbers: This is the Buddhas’ true teaching.
Buddha’s light shines everywhere, Destroying all darkness and gloom; This light neither has radiance Nor does not have radiance.
It has no attachment to things, No thought and no defilement, No abode and no location, And does not destroy the nature of things.
Herein there is no dualism, Yet neither is there oneness; One who sees well with great knowledge Skillfully abides according to truth.
No mean and no duality, And not even any nonduality: All in the worlds is void— This is the vision of the Buddhas.
People with no awakened understanding Buddha makes abide in the truth. All things have no abode— Understanding this, one sees one’s own body
Is not a body, yet said to be so; Is not born yet manifests birth: No body and no view— This is the unexcelled Buddha-body.
Thus has True Wisdom explained The nature of Buddhas’ subtle teaching; Any who hear this teaching Will attain the pure eye.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dam pa'i blo gros kyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad de smras pa/
Then the enlightening being Stable Wisdom, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

drin gzo med pa'i sems can phyir/ / skyes bu drang srong mchog gi rnams/ / dpa' chen sems can gtso bo dag / 'od mdzad pa ni rab tu byung / /
thugs rje chen po bskyed mdzad de/ / sems can khams la rnam gzigs kyang / / srid pa'i bcings pas sdug bsngal ba'i/ / sems can rnams ni de nas gzigs/ /
'jig rten lha dang bcas pa na/ / yang dag sangs rgyas dpal mnga' ba/ / sems can gtso bo ma gtogs par/ / skyob pa gzhan ni gang yang med/ /
gal te sangs rgyas ma skyes la/ / byang chub sems dpa' 'di 'dra dag / med na 'jig rten khams kun na/ / sems can bde ba gcig mi 'byung / /
sems can gtso bo 'dren mdzad pa/ / de bzhin gshegs pa skyes pa dang / / byang chub sems dpa' 'di 'dra dag / 'byung ba 'jig rten bde ba'i rgyu/ /
gang gis de bzhin gshegs mthor ba/ / de dag 'thob pa legs par thob/ / gang gis thos shing dad 'gyur ba/ / de yang 'jig rten mchod rten no/ /
gang gis sangs rgyas mthong gyur pa/ / bdag cag rnams kyis thob legs thob/ / 'di dang 'dra ba'i tshul thos pas/ / kun kyang yang dag sangs rgyas 'gyur/ /
'das pa'i dus na'ang dpal 'di yod/ / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi/ / shes rab mig ni rnam sbyangs bas/ / spyod yul 'di dag mthong bar 'gyur/ /
rnam par snang mdzad thub mthong nas/ / da dung phyir zhing dad pa skye/ / de yi ye shes mtha' yas pas/ / da dung brjod du yod pa min/ /
gang zhig mchog gi blos smras dang / / rgyal sras gzhan gyis bshad pa rnams/ / de dag da dung bdag gis kyang / / bskal pa bsam yas bshad par bya/ /

How grand, the Great Light, The vigorous Unsurpassed Hero, Who appears in the world To help the confused.
The Buddha observes all beings With a heart of great compassion, Seeing them in the three realms of existence Suffering over and over.
Except for the Truly Enlightened, The honored Guide, full of virtue, There is none who can rescue All human and heavenly beings.
If the Buddhas and enlightening beings Did not appear in the world, There would not be a single creature Who could have peace and ease.
The Buddha, rightly awakened, As well as the sages and saints, Appear in the world, Able to bestow happiness on beings.
If someone sees the Buddha, That is gaining great benefit; Hearing the name Buddha and developing faith Is a monument in the world.
We see the World Honored Ones And consider it a great boon; Hearing such a wonderful teaching, We all shall attain enlightenment.
The enlightening beings, in the past, By the spiritual power of Buddha, Attained the pure eye of wisdom And perceived the realms of the Buddhas.
Now we see Vairocana And grow doubly in pure faith. Buddha’s knowledge is boundless And cannot be fully explained.
Even if the enlightening beings Such as Supreme Wisdom, and I, Stable Wisdom, Were to speak for countless eons, We could not tell it all.

shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ ri rab kyi rtse mor de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i tshogs kyi tshigs su bcad pa'i le'u ste/ bcu dgu pa'o// //
[20. byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dgod pa bcu bstan pa'i le'u]
BOOK FIFTEEN. The Ten Abodes
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba theg pa chen po'i mdo/ bam po nyi shu gcig pa/

de nas byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyis de'i tshe sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis sbyor ba mtha' yas pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la mnyam par bzhag go / de ltar byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyis byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin sbyor ba mtha' yas pa zhes bya ba de la mnyam par bzhag ma thag tu de'i mod la phyogs bcu'i phyogs re re'i 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi pha rol nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kun kyang chos kyi blo gros zhes bya bar mthun pa sha stag gis zhal mngon par bstan pa mthong bar gyur te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis 'di skad ces kyang bka' stsal te; chos kyi blo gros/ khyod de ltar byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin sbyor ba mtha' yas pa la mnyam par gzhog pa legs so/ / legs so/ / de bas na rigs kyi bu/ khyod la phyogs bcu nas de bzhin gshegs pa sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kun kyang mtshan mthun pa sha stag gis bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa rnam par snang mdzad kyi sngon gyi smon lam dang / khyod bdag gi dge ba'i rtsa bas nye bar bstan pas 'di lta ste/ chos thams cad bstan par bya ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi ye shes rnam par 'phel bar bya ba dang / chos kyi dbyings su chud par bya ba dang / sems can gyi khams rnam par bsgom pa dang / chags pa med pa nyid du chud par bya ba dang / bsgribs pa med pa'i spyod yul thob par bya ba dang / kun nas sbyor ba thob par bya ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid yongs su gzung bar bya ba dang / chos thams cad khong du chud par bya ba dang / dbang po thams cad yongs su shes par bya ba dang / chos bstan pa thams cad yongs su gzung ba dang / 'di lta ste/ byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dgod pa bcu la rtsom par bya ba'i phyir byin gyis brlabs pa mdzad kyi/ rigs kyi bu/ khyod kyis sangs rgyas kyi mthu dang / sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis chos bstan pa 'di la spobs pa skyed cig /

THEN THE ENLIGHTENING BEING Truth Wisdom, empowered by the Buddha, entered into the concentration of infinite techniques of enlightening beings; by the power of concentration there appeared before him Buddhas as numerous as atoms in a thousand buddha-fields from each of the ten directions beyond as many worlds as atoms in a thousand buddha-fields: all of those Buddhas had the same name, Truth Wisdom. They said to the enlightening being Truth Wisdom, “Excellent! Excellent, good man, that you are able to enter this enlightening being’s concentration of infinite techniques. Good man, in each of the ten directions as many Buddhas as atoms in a thousand buddha-fields all together empower you with their spiritual force, and this is also the spiritual power of the force of Vairocana Buddha’s ancient vows, as well as the power of the roots of goodness you have cultivated, whereby you enter this concentration, allowing you to expound the teaching, for growth in enlightened knowledge, to enter deeply into the realm of reality, to comprehend well the worlds of sentient beings, to be unhindered in whatever is entered into, to be unobstructed in all activities, to attain incomparable skill in means, to enter the essence of omniscience, to be aware of all things, to know all faculties, to be able to hold and expound all the teachings; that is to say, bringing forth the ten abodes of enlightening beings. Good man, you should receive the spiritual power of the Buddhas and expound this teaching.”

de nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros la chags pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / thogs pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / mchod pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / rmongs pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / tha dad pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / kha na ma tho ba med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / dpag tu med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / zhum pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / 'phrog pa med pa nye bar sgrub pa mdzad do/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ting nge 'dzin 'di nyid kyi chos nyid thob pa'i phyir ro; ;

Then the Buddhas gave the enlightening being Truth Wisdom unhindered knowledge, unattached knowledge, unbroken knowledge, knowledge free from ignorance, unvarying knowledge, knowledge without loss, immeasurable knowledge, unexcelled knowledge, unremitting knowledge, and knowledge that cannot be taken away. Why? Because the power of this concentration is naturally this way in principle.

de nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gis byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyi spyi bo la phyag g.yas pas byug pa mdzad de/ de ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gi phyag gis reg ma thag tu byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros ting nge 'dzin de las langs te byang chub sems dpa' de dag la smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa'i rigs zhes bya ba 'di ni/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa/ nam mkha'i mthas gtugs pas shin tu yangs pa ste/ de la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni; 'das pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi rigs su skye ba yin/ ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi rigs su skye ba yin/ da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi rigs su skye ba yin/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa' brtson par byed pa gang las bsam ste de skad du smras pa de dag gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /bcu po 'di dag ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa ste/ 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis gsungs pa dang / gsung ba dang / gsung bar 'gyur ba dag go /bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / rnal 'byor la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / cher skyes pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / gzhon nur gyur pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / rgyal tshab kyi byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa dang / dbang bskur ba'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po de dag ni/ byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa ste/ 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis gsungs pa dang / gsung ba dang / gsung bar 'gyur ba dag go /

Now the Buddhas all extended their right hands and rubbed Truth Wisdom’s head; then the enlightening being Truth Wisdom emerged from concentration and declared to the enlightening beings, “Children of Buddhas, the abode of enlightening beings is vast, as vast as the space of the cosmos. Enlightening beings dwell in the house of the Buddhas of past, present, and future. The abodes of enlightening beings I shall now explain. Buddha-children, there are ten kinds of abodes of enlightening beings, which the past, future, and present Buddhas have explained, will explain, and do explain. What are the ten? They are the abode of initial determination; the abode of preparing the ground; the abode of practice action; the abode of noble birth; the abode of fulfillment of skill in means; the abode of the correct state of mind; the abode of nonregression; the abode of youthful nature; the abode of prince of the teaching; the abode of coronation. These are called the ten abodes of enlightening beings, expounded by the Buddhas of past, future, and present.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams mthong nas mdzes pa dang / bzang ba dang / mig tu thong ba dang / kha dog rgyas pa dang / thub par dka' ba dang / mthu che bar mthong ba'o/ / rdzu 'phrul gyi rnam par 'phrul ba dang / yongs su bstan pa'i rnam par 'phrul ba dang / rjes su bstan pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa mthong ba'am/ sems can sdug bsngal ba mthong ba'am/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos rgya chen po thos par gyur nas thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du smon cing / snga phyi med par byang chub tu sems bskyed de/ sems bskyed pa dang po des ni/ thub par dka' ba'i gnas bcu yongs su bzung bar 'gyur te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar gnas dang gnas ma yin pa shes pa dang / las kyi rnam par smin pa shes pa dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa dang rnam par byang ba shes pa dang / dbang po dang / brtson 'grus rnam pa tha dad pa yongs su rdzogs pa mchog dang tha ma shes pa dang / mos pa tha dad pa dang mos pa du ma shes pa dang / khams tha dad pa dang khams du ma shes pa dang / thams cad du 'gro ba'i lam shes pa dang / bsam gtan dang / rnam par thar pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / snyoms par 'jug pa dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa dang / rnam par byang ba shes pa dang / rjes su dran pa bsgribs pa med pa shes pa dang / chags pa med pa'i lha'i mig shes pa dang / dus gsum mnyam pa nyid du zag pa med pa shes pa'o/ / thub par dka' ba'i gnas bcu po de dag yongs su zin par 'gyur te/ de ni/ sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa'o// kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar byang chub sems dpa' sems dang po bskyed pa de ni/ sangs rgyas mchod pa la sbyar bar bya ba ste/ byang chub sems dpa' bsten par bde ba yang de la brjod par bya'o/ / 'jig rten gyi nang na gtso bor gyur pa yang de la brjod par bya'o/ / phul du phyin pa yang de la brjod par bya'o/ / zil gyis mi non pa'i gnas kyang de la brjod par bya'o// sangs rgyas kyi bdag nyid che ba yang de la bstan par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas tshad med pa dang 'phrad par 'gyur ba yang de la bstan par bya'o/ / rab tu zhi ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sbyor ba yang de la brjod par bya'o/ / 'khor ba'i 'khor lo las ldog par 'gyur ba yang de la brjod par bya'o/ / sems can sdug bsngal ba yongs su bskyab pa yang de la brjod par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na; sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la de bas kyang shas cher sems skye bar bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang de la bdag nyid sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring 'jog par mi 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of initial determination? The enlightening beings, seeing the magnificence of the Buddhas, which people like to see, rarely encountered, having great power; or seeing their spiritual powers, or hearing predictions of enlightenment, or listening to their teachings and instructions, or seeing sentient beings suffering severe pains, or hearing the far-reaching teaching of enlightenment of the Buddhas, develop the determination for enlightenment, to seek omniscience. The enlightening beings arouse determination with ten difficult-to-attain objectives: the knowledge of what is so and what is not; knowledge of consequences of good and bad actions; knowledge of superiority and inferiority of faculties; knowledge of the differences of various understandings; knowledge of the differences of various realms; knowledge of where all paths lead; knowledge of all meditations, liberations, and concentrations; knowledge of past lives; clairvoyance; knowledge of the universal end of indulgence for all time. Here the enlightening beings should encourage and study ten things: diligently making offerings to the Buddhas; gladly remaining in the world; guiding worldly people to reject evil deeds; always carrying on instruction by means of the most sublime teaching; praising the unexcelled teaching; learning the virtues of buddhahood; being born in the presence of Buddhas and always being received into their company; expediently expounding tranquil concentration; extolling detachment from the cycle of birth and death; being a refuge for suffering beings. What is the reason? To cause enlightening beings’ minds to broaden in the Buddha’s teaching and to be able to understand whatever teaching they hear without depending on another’s instruction.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' thog ma nyid du sems can thams cad la rnam pa bcur sems nye bar gzhog ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ phan pa'i sems nye bar gzhog go /snying brtse ba'i sems dang / bde ba'i sems dang / gnas pa'i sems dang / byams pa'i sems dang / phan 'dogs pa'i sems dang / yongs su srung ba'i sems dang / mnyam pa'i sems dang / slob dpon gyi sems dang / ston pa'i sems nye bar gzhog go /rnam pa bcu po de dag gis sems can thams cad la sems nye bar gzhog ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa'o, /kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa de ni/ thog ma nyid du kha ton la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / mang du thos nas dben par gnas pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / rab tu dben par gyur nas dge ba'i bshes su 'gyur bar yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / dge ba'i bshes su gyur nas nga lo bde ba la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / nga lo bde bar gyur nas dus shes pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / dus shes nas mi 'jigs pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / mi 'jigs par gyur nas don shes pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / don shes nas chos kyi rjes su 'brang ba la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / chos kyi rjes su 'gro bar gyur nas rmongs pa med pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / rmongs pa med par gyur nas rnam par dgod pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sems can thams cad de la de bas kyang shes cher snying rje chen po mngon du gzhog par bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang de la bdag nyid sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring 'jog par mi 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of preparing the ground? Here the enlightening beings develop ten attitudes toward all living beings: altruism; compassion; wish to give happiness; wish to give security; pity; care; protecting; identification; considering them as teachers; considering them as guides. Here the enlightening beings should encourage and study ten things: study and learning; uncluttered tranquility; association with the wise; gentle, pleasing speech; speech appropriate to the occasion; fearlessness; understanding; acting in accord with the teaching; avoiding folly and delusion; stability. What is the reason? To cause enlightening beings to increase great compassion toward sentient beings, and to immediately understand whatever teachings they hear without relying on the instruction of another.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la rnal 'byor la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' dmigs pa'i rnam pa bcus chos thams cad la brtson par byed de/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar chos thams cad mi rtag pa dang / chos thams cad sdug bsngal ba dang / chos thams cad stong pa nyid dang / chos thams cad bdag med pa dang / chos thams cad byed pa med pa dang / chos thams cad myong ba med pa dang / chos thams cad brda med pa dang / chos thams cad gnas med pa dang / chos thams cad rnam par rtog pa med pa dang / chos thams cad ched du byed pa med pa ste/ dmigs pa'i rnam pa bcu po de dag gis chos kyi rjes su 'brang ba'i tshul du brtson par byed de/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ rnal 'byor la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras ngag /de ltar rnal 'byor la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de ni/ sems can gyi khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / chos kyi khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / 'jig rten gyi khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / sa'i khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / chu'i khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / me'i khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / rlung gi khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / 'dod pa'i khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / gzugs kyi khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / gzugs med pa'i khams brtag pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bas kyang chos la snang ba 'byung ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang de la bdag nyid sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring 'jog par mi 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ rnal 'byor la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of practice? Here enlightening beings contemplate all things through ten practices: observing that all things are impermanent, all things are painful, all things are empty, all things are selfless, all things have no creation, all things are flavorless, all things do not correspond to the names, all things have no locus, all things are apart from discrimination, all things lack stable solidity. Here the enlightening beings should encourage and study ten things: observing the realms of sentient beings, the realms of phenomena and principles, and the realms of the world; observing the elements of earth, water, fire, and air; observing the realms of desire, form, and formlessness. What is the reason? To cause enlightening beings’ knowledge to be perfectly clear, so they can immediately understand any teaching they hear without depending on the instruction of another.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la cher skyes pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'phags pa'i gsung rab la yongs su smin pa bcus skyes pa yin te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar phyir mi ldog pa dang / sangs rgyas la shes pas mos pa'i mthar phyin pa dang / chos nges par rtogs pa dang / sems can rnam par bsgoms pa dang / zhing rnam par bsgoms pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par bsgoms pa dang / las rnam par bsgoms pa dang / rnam par smin pa rnam par bsgoms pa dang / 'khor ba rnam par bsgoms pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa rnam par bsgoms pa ste/ yongs su smin pa bcu po 'di dag gis 'phags pa'i gsung rab las skyes pa yin te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ cher skyes pa'i byang chub sems dpa'o/ / de ltar cher skyes pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de ni/ 'das pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi chos rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas kyi chos rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas kyi chos rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kyi chos yang dag par sgrub pa rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas kyi chos yang dag par sgrub par bya ba rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas kyi chos yang dag par sgrub pa rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su sgrub pa rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su bsgrub par bya ba rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su sgrub pa rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o/ / sangs rgyas mnyam pa nyid rnam par sgom pa la yongs su bskul bar bya'o; ; de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de dus gsum mnyam pa nyid la de bas kyang sems 'jug par bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang de la bdag nyid sbyor ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring la 'jog par mi bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ cher skyes pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of noble birth? Here the enlightening beings are born from the wise teaching and perfect ten things: never regressing from the presence of the Buddhas; profoundly engendering pure faith; carefully examining things; thoroughly knowing living beings, lands, worlds, actions, consequences, birth and death, and nirvana. Here the enlightening beings should encourage and study ten things: knowing all past, future, and present Buddhas’ teachings; practicing and accumulating all past, future, and present Buddhas’ teachings; fulfilling all past, future, and present Buddhas’ teachings; and knowing that all Buddhas are equal. What is the reason? To cause progress in equanimity in respect to past, present, and future, and to be able to understand any teaching heard without relying on the instruction of another.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i rtsa ba gang ci rtsom yang rung ste/ de thams cad sems can thams cad yongs su bskyab pa'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad la phan par bya ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad yongs su dgrol bar bya ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad la snying brtse ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad yongs su dgrol bar bya ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad la gnod pa med par bya ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad drang ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad dang bar bya ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad gdul ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ / sems can thams cad yongs su mya ngan las bzla ba'i phyir rtsom mo/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ste/ sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de la ni/ sems can mtha' yas pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can tshad med pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can grangs med pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can bsam gyis mi khyab pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can gzugs med pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can dpag tu med pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can stong pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can byed pa med pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can dngos po med pa brjod par bya'o/ / sems can rang bzhin med pa brjod par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na; de'i sems de bas kyang shas cher mngon par zhen pa la mi gnas par bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang de la bdag nyid sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog par bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of fulfilling skill in means? Here the roots of goodness cultivated by the enlightening beings are all to save all sentient beings, to benefit all sentient beings, to cause all sentient beings to be free from calamities and difficulties, to cause all sentient beings to leave the miseries of birth and death, to cause all sentient beings to develop pure faith, to cause all sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified, to cause all sentient beings to experience nirvana. Here the enlightening beings should encourage and learn ten things: to know sentient beings are boundless, to know sentient beings are infinite, to know sentient beings are countless, to know sentient beings are inconceivable, to know sentient beings’ infinite forms, to know sentient beings are immeasurable, to know sentient beings are empty, to know sentient beings create nothing, to know sentient beings possess nothing, to know sentient beings have no identity. What is the reason? To cause the mind to increase in mastery and have no attachments, and to immediately understand any teaching heard without depending on the instruction of another.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' chos bcu nyan na/ bsam pa nges pa rab tu 'thob pa yin te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar sangs rgyas la snyan pa'am/ mi snyan par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ chos la snyan pa dang / mi snyan par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ byang chub sems dpa' la snyan pa'am/ mi snyan par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la snyan ba'am mi snyan par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ sems can gyi khams chung ba dang / sems can gyi khams che ba brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ sems can gyi khams kun nas nyon mongs pa dang / sems can gyi khams kun nas nyon mongs pa med par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ sems can gyi khams skyo bar sla ba dang / sems can gyi khams skyo bar dka' ba brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin; chos kyi dbyings chung ba'am/ chos kyi dbyings che bar brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ chos kyi dbyings 'grub pa'am/ chos kyi dbyings 'jig par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ chos kyi dbyings yod pa'am/ chos kyi dbyings med par brjod kyang sangs rgyas kyi chos la bsam pa nges pa yin/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ni/ byang chub sems dpa' bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa ste/ de ltar bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de la chos la 'jug pa bcu brjod par bya ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar chos thams cad mtshan ma med pa dang / chos thams cad mtshan nyid med pa dang / chos thams cad dngos po med pa dang / chos thams cad yod pa ma yin pa dang / chos thams cad rdzun pa dang / chos thams cad dben pa dang / chos thams cad rang bzhin med pa dang / chos thams cad sgyu ma lta bu dang / chos thams cad rmi lam lta bu dang / chos thams cad rtog pa med pa brjod par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de'i bsam pa de bas kyang shas cher mi 'phrog pa la rnam par bsgrub par bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang bdag nyid de la sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring 'jog par mi 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of the correct state of mind? Here the enlightening being’s mind is steady and unwavering even when hearing these ten things: hearing the Buddha praised or reviled, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing the teaching praised or reviled, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing enlightening beings praised or reviled, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing the practices of enlightening beings praised or reviled, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing it said that living beings are finite or infinite, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing it said that sentient beings are defiled or undefiled, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing it said that sentient beings are easy to liberate or difficult to liberate, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing it said that there is becoming or disintegration of the universe, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching; hearing it said that the universe exists or does not exist, the mind is steady and unwavering in regard to the Buddha’s teaching. Here the enlightening being should study and encourage the study of ten things: that all things are signless; all things are insubstantial; all things cannot be cultivated; all things have no existence; all things have no true reality; all things are empty; all things lack inherent nature; all things are like illusions; all things are like dreams; all things have no discrimination. What is the reason? To cause the mind to progress further to attain nonregressing acceptance of the nonorigination of things, and immediately understand whatever teaching is heard, without depending on the instruction of another.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' dmigs pa bcu nyan pa'i tshe brtan pa rab tu 'thob ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar sangs rgyas yod ce'am, sangs rgyas med ce na'ang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /chos yod ce'am/ chos med ce na'ang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa yod ce'am/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa med ce na yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /byang chub sems dpa' byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'byung zhe'am/ byang chub sems dpa' byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la mi 'byung zhe na yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /de bzhin gshegs pa 'das she'am/ de bzhin gshegs pa ma 'das shen yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /de bzhin gshegs pa byon ce'am, de bzhin gshegs pa byon pa ma yin zhe na yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /sangs rgyas da ltar byung ba zhe'am/ sangs rgyas da ltar byung ba ma yin zhe na yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /sangs rgyas kyi ye shes zad mi shes so; ; zhe'am, sangs rgyas kyi ye shes zad shes so/ / zhe na yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /dus gsum mtshan nyid gcig ce'am/ dus gsum mtshan nyid tha dad ce na yang sangs rgyas kyi chos las phyir mi ldog go /kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ste/ de ltar phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de la ni/ chos 'byams klas pa bcu brjod par bya ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ gcig las rnam pa tha dad par 'gyur ba brjod par bya'o/ / mang po las tha mi dad par brjod par bya'o/ / don dang mthun pa'i yi ge brjod par bya'o/ / yi ge dang mthun pa'i don brjod par bya'o/ / dngos po med pa yod pa dang mnyam pa nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / dngos po yod pa med pa dang mnyam pa nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / mtshan ma med pa mtshan ma dang mnyam pa nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / mtshan ma mtshan ma med pa dang mnyam pa nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / mtshan nyid med pa mtshan nyid dang mnyam pa nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / mtshan nyid mtshan nyid med pa dang mnyam pa nyid du brjod par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ci nas kyang de bas kyang shas cher mkhas pa thams cad la yongs su byang bar 'byung ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang bdag nyid de la sbyor bar bya dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog par 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of nonregression? Here the enlightening being remains firm and doesn’t regress even when hearing these ten things: hearing that Buddhas do or do not exist, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that truth exists or does not exist, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that enlightening beings do or do not exist, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that enlightening beings’ practices do or do not exist, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that enlightening beings do or do not attain emancipation through their practices, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that there were or were not Buddhas in the past, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that there will or will not be Buddhas in the future, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing there are or are not Buddhas in the present, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that a Buddha’s knowledge is finite or infinite, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching; hearing that past, present, and future are uniform or not uniform, the mind does not regress in the Buddha’s teaching. Here the enlightening being should encourage and study ten far-reaching principles: explaining one is many; explaining many are one; literary expression according with meaning; meaning according with literary expression; nonexistence is existence; existence is nonexistence; formless is form; form is formlessness; nature is natureless; naturelessness is nature. What is the reason? To progress further, to be able to gain emancipation from all things, to understand any teaching without relying on another’s instruction.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / de la gzhon nur gyur pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa' las bcu la gnas pa yin te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar lus kyi spyod pa kha na ma tho ba med pa yin/ ngag gi spyod pa kha na ma tho ba med pa yin/ yid kyi spyod kha na ma tho ba med pa yin/ sems bskyed pa tsam gyis skye ba sgrub pa yin/ sems can gzhan gyi bsam pa shes pa yin/ gang zag gzhan gyi mos pa rtogs pa yin/ sems can gyi khams tha dad pa rab tu shes pa yin/ las kyi byin gyis rlabs tha dad pa rab tu rtogs pa yin; 'jig rten gyi khams 'grub pa dang 'jig pa yongs su 'jal ba yin/ gang dga' bar 'gro ba la myur ba yin/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ gzhon nur gyur pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar gzhon nur gyur pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de la ni/ chos mngon par sgrub pa bcu brjod par bya'o/ / bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste; sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su shes pa brjod par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi zhing rab tu bskyed pa brjod par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi byin gyis brlabs brjod par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi zhing du rnam par rgyu ba brjod par bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su mnan pa brjod par bya'o/ / 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par 'gro ba brjod par bya'o/ / chos grangs med pa yongs su dri ba brjod par bya'o/ / yid kyi rang bzhin gyi lus mngon par sgrub pa brjod par bya'o/ / dbyangs kyi sbyor ba rab tu dgye ba brjod par bya'o/ / sems bskyed pa gcig las sangs rgyas grangs med pa bsnyen bkur bar bya ba brjod par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bas kyang shas cher chos thams cad la mngon par sgrub pa'i mkhas pa 'byung bar bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang de la bdag nyid sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring 'jog par mi 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ gzhon nur gyur pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of youthful nature? Here the enlightening being abides in ten kinds of activity: physically acting without error; verbally acting without error; mentally acting without error; being born at will; knowing the various desires of sentient beings; knowing the various understandings of sentient beings; knowing the various realms of sentient beings; knowing the various activities of sentient beings; knowing the becoming and decay of the world; going anywhere freely by psychic projection. Here the enlightening being should encourage and study ten kinds of things: knowing all buddha-lands; activating all buddha-lands, maintaining all buddha-lands; observing all buddha-lands; visiting all buddha-lands; traveling in countless worlds; receiving innumerable teachings of Buddhas; manifesting a body with freedom to metamorphose; producing a far-reaching, universal voice; serving and providing for countless Buddhas in a single instant. What is the reason? To advance in skillfulness in applying teachings, to be able to understand any teaching without depending on another’s instructions.
