kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /rgyal tshab kyi byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa' chos bcu rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar sems can gyi skye ba rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ nyon mongs pa'i rgyud rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ bag chags kyi mchams 'brel pa rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ spyod yul rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ chos sna tshogs rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ spyad pa rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par phye ba rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ sngon gyi mtha' dang phyi ma'i mtha' shes par rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ 'jig rten gyi kun rdzob kyi bden pa brtag pa rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ don dam pa'i bden pa brtag pa rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ rgyal tshab kyi byang chub sems dpa' ste/ byang chub sems dpa' rgyal tshab de la ni/ gnas bcu brjod par bya'o/ / bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ rgyal po'i gnas la mkhas pa brjod par bya'o/ / rgyal po'i gnas kyi tshul brjod par bya'o/ / rgyal po'i gnas su gnas pa brjod par bya'o/ / rgyal po'i gnas su 'gro ba brjod par bya'o/ / rgyal po'i gnas su spyod pa brjod par bya'o/ / chos kyi rgyal por dbang bskur ba brjod par bya'o/ / chos kyi rgyal po'i byin brjod par bya'o/ / chos kyi rgyal po'i mthu brjod par bya'o/ / chos kyi rgyal srid la gnas pa brjod par bya'o/ / chos kyi rgyal po'i bsngags pa brjod par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ci nas kyang de'i sems bsgribs pa med pa mngon par bsgrubs pa la de bas kyang shas cher gnas par bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang bdag nyid de la sbyor bar bya ba dang / bdag nyid gzhan gyi dring 'jog par mi bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ rgyal tshab kyi byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode as the prince of the teaching? Here enlightening beings know ten things well: they know how sentient beings are born; they know the origin of afflictions; they know the continuation of habit energy; they know what techniques are to be employed; they know innumerable teachings; they understand all modes of dignified behavior; they know the differentiations of the world; they know past and future events; they know how to explain conventional truth; they know how to explain ultimate truth. Here the enlightening beings should study and encourage the study of ten things: the skills proper to a king of the teaching; the regulations and manners proper to a king of the teaching; the abode of a king of the teaching; that which a king of the teaching enters into; the contemplations proper to a king of the teaching; the coronation of a king of the teaching; the power and sustenance of a king of the teaching; the fearlessness of a king of the teaching; the repose of a king of the teaching; the praise of a king of the teaching. What is the reason? To promote progress in nonobstruction of mind, to understand any teaching spontaneously without relying on the instruction of another.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de la dbang bskur ba'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di la byang chub sems dpa'i ye shes la rnam par spyod pa bcu dang ldan pa yin te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa yongs su bskyed pa'i sems mang ba yin/ 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa snang bar bya ba'i sems mang ba yin/ 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa byin gyis brlab pa'i sems mang ba yin; 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa 'da' bar bya ba'i sems mang ba yin/ 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa yongs su sbyang ba'i sems mang ba yin/ sems can grangs med pa rnam par dmigs par bya ba'i sems mang ba yin/ sems can grangs med pa rnam par brtag pa'i sems mang ba yin/ sems can grangs med pa'i dbang po rtogs par bya ba'i sems mang ba yin/ sems can grangs med pa yongs su gzung ba'i sems mang ba yin/ sems can grangs med pa gdul ba'i sems mang ba yin te/ de'i lus ni / byang chub sems dpa' rgyal tshab la gnas pa'i bar gyis kyang shes par mi nus te/ lus kyi las shes par mi nus so/ / rdzu 'phrul shes par mi nus so/ / rdzu 'phrul gyi rnam par 'phrul pa shes par mi nus so/ / 'das par blta ba'am shes par mi nus so/ / ma 'ongs pa blta ba'am shes par mi nus so/ / da ltar byung ba blta ba'am shes par mi nus so/ / zhing mngon par 'du byed pa shes par mi nus so/ / sems kyi yul shes par mi nus so/ / ye shes kyi spyod yul yang byang chub sems dpa' rgyal tshab la gnas pa'i bar gyis shes par mi nus te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ dbang bskur ba'i byang chub sems dpa'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa' dbang bskur ba de la ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis ye shes la 'jug pa bcu bka' stsal te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar dus gsum gyi ye shes brjod pa mdzad do/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi ye shes brjod pa mdzad do/ / chos kyi dbyings chags pa med pa brjod pa mdzad do/ / chos kyi dbyings mtha' dang dbus med pa brjod pa mdzad do/ / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad rgyas par dgang ba brjod pa mdzad do/ / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad snang bar bya ba brjod pa mdzad do/ / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad byin gyis brlabs pa brjod pa mdzad do/ / sems can thams cad yongs su shes pa'i ye shes brjod pa mdzad do/ / chos thams cad yongs su shes pa'i ye shes brjod pa mdzad do/ / sangs rgyas mtha' yas pa brjod pa mdzad do/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ci nas kyang de'i sems rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du de bas kyang shas cher gnas par bya ba dang / gnas gang thos kyang bdag nyid de la sbyor bar bya ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog par bya ba'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'di ni/ dbang bskur ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dgod pa'o/ /

“What is the enlightening beings’ abode of coronation? Here the enlightening being perfects ten kinds of knowledge: shaking countless worlds; illuminating countless worlds; supporting countless worlds; traveling to countless worlds; purifying countless worlds; teaching countless sentient beings; observing countless sentient beings; knowing the faculties of countless sentient beings; causing countless sentient beings to strive to enter enlightenment; causing countless sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified. This enlightening being’s body and physical activities, various manifestations of spiritual powers, past, future, and present knowledge, development of a buddha-land, state of mind, and realm of knowledge are all unknowable: even an enlightening being in the station of prince of the teaching cannot know them. Here the enlightening being should promote and study ten kinds of knowledge proper to Buddhas: knowledge of past, present, and future; knowledge of enlightening teachings; knowledge of the harmony of the universe; knowledge of the boundlessness of the universe; knowledge filling all worlds; knowledge illumining all worlds; knowledge supporting all worlds; knowledge of all sentient beings; knowledge of all things; knowledge of the infinite Buddhas. What is the reason? To increase in knowledge of all particulars and all means of liberation and spontaneously understand any teaching without depending on the instruction of another.”

de nas de'i tshe sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcur 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed rnam pa drug tu g.yos so/ / rab tu g.yos so/ / kun tu g.yos so/ / 'gul to/ / rab tu 'gul to/ / kun tu 'gul to/ / ldeg go /rab tu ldeg go /kun tu ldeg go /chem chem/ rab tu chem chem/ kun tu chem chem mo/ / 'ur 'ur/ rab tu 'ur 'ur/ kun tu 'ur 'ur ro/ / shig shig /rab tu shig shig / kun tu shig shig go /sangs rgyas kyi mthu dang chos nyid thob pas lha rdzas kyi me tog gi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi phye ma'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi phreng ba'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi spos kyi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi gos kyi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi rin po che'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi lhab lhub kyi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ / lha rdzas kyi rol mo'i sgra mngon par byung bar gyur to/ / lha rdzas kyi snang ba rab tu byung bar gyur to/ / lha rdzas kyi nga ro shin tu grags par gyur to/ / gling bzhi pa 'di'i ri rab kyi rtse mor lha'i dbang po'i khang pa ji lta ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du yang phyogs bcu rgyas par byung ste/ chos bstan pa 'di yang thams cad du byung ngo/ / sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi byang chub sems dpa' mang po lhags te phyogs bcu rgyas par bkang nas 'di skad ces 'dzer to/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar khyod byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi chos nyid de lta bu ston pa legs so/ / legs so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /bdag cag kun kyang ming chos kyi blo gros zhes bya ba sha stag ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan chos kyi blo gros zhes bya ba sha stag gi zham ring / 'jig rten gyi khams chos kyi sprin ces bya ba sha stag nas 'dir phyin te/ thams cad na yang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis chos bstan pa 'di nyid 'khor gyi rnam pa 'di lta bu dag tu tshig 'di dag dang / yi ge 'di dag dang / khong du chud par bya ba 'di dag gis don 'di nyid mngon par smos shing / lhag chad med par ston te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar bdag cag dbang du gyur pa sha stag sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis 'dir phyin to/ / ji ltar bdag cag 'jig rten gyi khams 'dir phyin pa de bzhin du/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi 'jig rten gyi khams re re'i gling bzhi pa dag gi ri rab kyi rtse mo'i lha'i dbang po'i khang pa dag tu yang byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed mang po phyin par gyur to/ /

Then, due to the spiritual power of the Buddha, in each of the ten directions as many worlds as atoms in ten thousand buddha-lands quaked in six ways; there rained celestial flowers, celestial incense powder, celestial garlands, celestial perfumes, celestial jewel raiment, celestial jewel clouds, celestial ornaments; celestial music spontaneously played, with radiant lights and exquisite sounds. As in this world on the peak of Mt. Sumeru, in the palace of King Indra, the ten abodes were expounded and supernatural manifestations appeared, so also did the same thing transpire in all worlds. And due to the spiritual power of the Buddha, in the ten directions, past as many worlds as atoms in ten thousand buddha-lands, there were as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands who came here, filling the ten directions, and said these words: “Excellent, excellent! O Child of Buddha, you have explained this teaching well. We too all have the same name, Truth Wisdom, and the lands we come from are all called Truth Cloud, and the Buddhas in those lands are all named Sublime Truth. In the presence of our Buddhas we too expound the ten abodes, and the congregations and followings, the words and phrases, the doctrines and principles, are all like this, with no addition or omission. Receiving spiritual power from the Buddha, we have come into this assembly to be witnesses for you. As it is in this assembly, so it is in all the worlds there are in the ten directions.”

de nas byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ chos kyi dbyings la rnam par bltas nas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Truth Wisdom, imbued with the power of the Buddha, looked over the ten directions, throughout the cosmos, and spoke these verses:

rang byung sangs rgyas thugs mchog rab mnga' ba/ / sku gzugs sku mdog shin tu mdzes ldan zhing / / mtshan bzang thub pa med pa mthong gyur nas/ / byang chub don du brtan pa sems bsgyur ro/ /
dpe zla med pa'i rdzu 'phrul stobs chen dang / / yongs su bstan dang rjes su bstan mthong ste/ / srid lam kun tu sdug bsngal gyur mthong zhing / / byang chub don du brtan pa sems bsgyur ro/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa yon tan kun mnga' ba/ / kun tu bzang po'i yon tan thos gyur cing / / nam mkha' dbyings mnyam rtog pa med pa yi/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bskyed do/ /
khams gsum kun na gnas ni 'di dag yin/ / gnas min rang bzhin dag kyang 'di yin zhes/ / ma nor dngos po khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bskyed do/ /
'das dang ma 'ongs da ltar byung ba dang / / dkar nag las rnams ji snyed yod pa dag / de kun mnyam nyid rjes su rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bskyed do/ /
bsam gtan ting 'dzin rnam par thar pa dang / / mnyam gzhag de bzhin kun nas nyon mongs dang / / rnam byang rnam par khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bskyed do/ /
sems can kun gyi dbang po ci 'dra dang / / brtson 'grus stobs kyang de bzhin ci 'dra ba/ / rnam pa sna tshogs de dag rtogs bya'i phyir/ / byang chub don du brtan pa sems bsgyur ro/ /
sems can kun gyi mos pa ji 'dra dang / / 'jig rten kun gyi bsam pa sna tshogs rnams/ / rnam pa kun tu thams cad rtogs bya'i phyir/ / byang chub don du brtan pa sems bsgyur ro/ /
'gro ba rnams kyi sna tshogs khams rnams dang / / 'jig rten kun gyi khams mang du ma dang / / khams kyi rang bzhin rtogs par bya ba'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
kun tu 'gro ba'i sems rnams ci 'dra dang / / lam rnams ci 'dra 'dus byas 'di dag gi / ma nor rang bzhin rtogs par bya ba'i phyir/ / byang chub don du brtan pa sems bsgyur ro/ /
zhing rnams thams cad mthong bar bya ba dang / / sems can 'di dag ji ltar 'khor gyur ces/ / chags med mig ni rnam par dag bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /

Seeing the subtle body of the Supremely Wise, Replete with adorning marks and refinements, So honorable and rare to meet, Enlightening beings boldly make their resolve.
Seeing incomparable great spiritual powers, Hearing tell of mind-reading and appropriate teaching, And the immeasurable sufferings of mundane beings, Enlightening beings thereby first become determined.
Hearing the Enlightened Ones, universally supremely honored, Have perfected all meritorious and virtuous qualities, Like space, not discriminating, Thereby do enlightening beings develop resolve.
The causes and effects of past, present, and future are called what is so; The inherent nature of self and phenomena is called what is not so. Wanting to know the genuine truth Do enlightening beings therefore arouse their will.
All the good and evil deeds there be In past, future, and present worlds Do they want to know completely; Therefore enlightening beings are determined.
All meditations, liberations, and concentrations, Defiled and pure, of countless kinds, They want to know all—entry, abiding, and exit; Therefore do enlightening beings arouse their aspiration.
According to the sharpness or dullness of beings’ faculties, So are their powers of effort also various; Wanting to understand and know them all distinctly, Do enlightening beings therefore arouse determination.
Sentient beings have various understandings And their mental inclinations are each different: Wanting to know all these innumerable inclinations Do enlightening beings therefore arouse their will.
The realms of sentient beings are each different; There is no measure to all the worlds there are: Wanting to know completely their substance and nature Do enlightening beings rouse their aspiration.
The paths of all fabricated actions Each have a destination; Wanting to know the true nature of all Do enlightening beings rouse their determination.
The sentient beings of all worlds Bob and flow according to their deeds, without cease; Wanting to attain the celestial eye to see them all Do enlightening beings rouse their will.

'das pa'i dus su gang rnams ci byung yang / / mtshan nyid gang yin ji 'dra ci dgongs pa/ / sngon gyi gnas rnams rjes su rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro; ;
'jig rten kun na kun sbyor ji snyed dang / / don gyi mtshams 'brel bag chags de bzhin te/ / nyon mongs zad bya mthar thug shes bya'i phyir/ / byang chub don du brtan pa sems bsgyur ro/ /
'gro ba rnams kyi tha snyad gdags pa dang / / tshig lam skad du brjod pa ji snyed pa/ / brda yi bden pa rjes su rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
chos rnams ji ltar brjod du med pa dang / / stong pa byed med rang bzhin dben pa'i rnams/ / de dag dngos nyid khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
zhing rnams thams cad rab tu bskyod pa dang / / rgya mtsho thams cad yongs su bskam bya bar/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rdzu 'phrul rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
spu rtse re re'i sgo nas 'od zer rnams/ / phyogs bcu kun tu ji ltar dgye bya ba/ / de 'dra'i rang bzhin khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
zhing rnams brjod med bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ / bdag gi lag pa'i mthil du gzhag bya bar/ / sgyu ma'i rnam pa thams cad rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
ji ltar zhing gi sems can yangs pa kun/ / gnod pa med par skra rtser gzhog byed par/ / srog med chos rnams khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
rgya mtsho thams cad chu chen gang rgyas pa/ / skra rtses blangs shing kun tu dor bya bar/ / mthar thug ma lus khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
ji ltar bsam gyis mi khyab zhing gi rnams/ / phra rab rdul glags ma lus bgrang bya bar/ / rdul phran grangs rnams khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
'das pa'i bskal pa de bzhin ma 'ongs dang / / 'jig rten tshig cing 'grub pa de bzhin te/ / bskal pa zad cing gnas pa shes bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /

Such constitutions and such characteristics As there were in past ages They want to know, as former lives, So enlightening beings arouse aspiration.
The continuity, appearance, and habit energy Of the binding delusions of all sentient beings They want to know thoroughly and finally, So enlightening beings thus rouse their will.
Of all the various philosophies and theories Which sentient beings may set up They want to know the worldly truth, So enlightening beings thus rouse determination.
All things are beyond speech— Their nature is empty, null, and creates nothing: Wishing to clearly arrive at this truth Do enlightening beings therefore rouse their will.
Wanting to shake the worlds of the ten directions And overturn all the oceans, Fulfilling the great spiritual powers of the Buddhas, Do enlightening beings rouse determination.
Wanting to emit lights from a single pore That will illumine infinite lands in the ten directions, In each light awakening all, Do enlightening beings therefore rouse aspiration.
Wanting to take inconceivably many buddha-lands And put them in their palms, without moving, Comprehending all is like magic illusions, So enlightening beings rouse their determination.
Wanting to take the beings of innumerable lands And put them on a hairtip without crowding, Knowing all have no person and no self, Therefore do enlightening beings arouse their will.
Wanting to take drops from the ocean on a hair So as to dry up all the oceans While specifically knowing the number of drops, Therefore do enlightening beings rouse their aspiration.
Reducing entirely to dust Inconceivable numbers of worlds, Wanting to know distinctly the number of particles Do enlightening beings arouse their will.
Wanting to comprehend exhaustively The signs of becoming and decay of all worlds In countless eons past and future Do enlightening beings rouse their aspiration.

dus gsum byung ba'i de bzhin gshegs pa dang / / rgyal sras rang rgyal nyan thos thams cad kyi/ / chos kyi rang bzhin khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
brjod du med pa'i 'jig rten khams kyi rnams/ / skra yi nyag mas bcings shing tshad gdab bar/ / dngos po'i rang bzhin khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
brjod med khor yug shin tu yangs pa dag / ba spu'i khung bu ji ltar gzung bya bar/ / phra dang yangs pa khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
phyogs bcu 'jig rten khams rnams thams cad du/ / ji ltar dbyangs gcig kun tu grags 'gyur bar/ / dbyangs kyi yan lag rnam dag shes bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
sems can kun gyi sgra skad ji snyed pa/ / dbyangs gcig brjod pas ji ltar brjod bya bar/ / sgra yi rang bzhin khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
'jig rten thams cad ma lus shes byed cing / / ji ltar 'gro kun zhi zhes ston 'gyur bar/ / lce yangs khong du chud par bya ba'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
zhing rnams thams cad rab tu tshig pa dang / / kun nas gnas pa ma lus mthong 'gyur bar/ / rnam rtogs chos ni khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
zhing rnams thams cad sangs rgyas gcig bzhin du/ / de bzhin gshegs pas ji ltar rgyas bya bar/ / rang byung chos ni rjes su rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
zhing rnams thams cad rdul mchog phrar glags pa/ / de snyed lus su ji ltar sprul bya bar/ / thams cad yid kyi dngos su shes bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
kun gzigs 'das pa ji snyed byung ba dang / / ma byon sangs rgyas de bzhin bzhugs pa rnams/ / skad cig sems kyis thams cad rtogs bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
tshig gcig brtsams te brjod cing bshad byas kyang / / bskal pa brjod med thams cad zad 'gyur bar/ / chos kyi rnam grangs khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /

Wanting to know all the teachings Of all the Buddhas of all times, All self-enlightened ones and Buddhas’ disciples, Do enlightening beings rouse their determination.
Wanting to pick up with a single hair Countless, boundless worlds And know their substances and forms as they are, Do enlightening beings rouse their will.
Wanting to put in a pore Countless mountain chains And know their sizes as they are Do enlightening beings rouse their aspiration.
Wanting to preach appropriately to all kinds of beings ever With the single subtle voice of tranquility and peace And cause them all to purely, clearly comprehend, Do enlightening beings rouse their determination.
To utter in a single word What is spoken by all sentient beings: Wanting to know all their inherent natures Do enlightening beings rouse their will.
Producing all spoken sounds of the worlds To make all realize peaceful dispassion: Wanting to attain such a marvelous tongue Do enlightening beings rouse their aspiration.
Wanting to cause all to see The signs of becoming and decay of all worlds And know they are born of conceptions Do enlightening beings rouse their determination.
All worlds in the ten directions Are filled with countless Buddhas; Wanting to know all the teachings of those Buddhas Do enlightening beings arouse their will.
Countless bodies of various transformations, Numerous as atoms in all worlds: Wanting to comprehend they all come from mind Do enlightening beings rouse this determination.
Wanting to know in a single thought The measureless, countless Buddhas Of past, future, and present worlds Do enlightening beings rouse this aspiration.
Wanting to expound the one phrase teaching For incalculable eons without exhausting it Yet have the expressions and nuances be each different Do enlightening beings therefore arouse this will.

phyogs bcu kun gyi 'jig rten ma lus rnams/ / 'byung zhing ji ltar rjes su 'brang ba dag / sems kyi rang bzhin khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
lus dang ngag dang de bzhin yid kyis kyang / / phyogs kun spyod tshe chags par mi 'gyur bar/ / dus gsum stong pa khong du chud bya'i phyir/ / brtan pa byang chub don du sems bsgyur ro/ /
de ltar byang chub don du sems bskyed pa/ / phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas brjod du med pa kun/ / mchod par bya la yongs su bskul bar bya/ / 'di ni phyir mi ldog gi gdams ngag go /
'khor ba dag na byang chub don spyod tshe/ / byang chub sems dpa'i bde ba ji snyed pa/ / de dag de la yongs su brjod par bya/ / 'di ni phyir mi ldog gi gdams ngag go /
'jig rten gtso bo 'jig rten ji snyed pa/ / phyogs bcu'i tha dad tshad med yod pa rnams/ / de dag byang chub sems dpa' de la brjod/ / 'di ni phyir mi ldog gi gdams ngag go /
mchog gi chos dang ji snyed dam pa'i chos/ / 'phrul gyi chos dang bla na med pa'i chos/ / de dag byang chub sems dpa' de la bstan/ / 'di ni skyon med rnams kyi gdams ngag go /
gzhan gyis mi thub ji snyed gnas yod pa/ / 'jig rten kun gyis zil gyis mi non rnams/ / de la gnas par rgyal sras de brjod de/ / 'di ni phyir mi ldog gi gdams ngag go /
de bzhin gshegs pa'i yon tan kun ldan pa/ / 'jig rten mgon po'i bdag nyid che ba kun/ / de la byang chub sems dpa' de bzhag ste; ; 'di ni skyes bu khyu mchog gdams ngag go /
sangs rgyas grangs med brjod du med pa dang / / ji ltar 'grogs par 'gyur ba thams cad kyang / / byang chub sems dpa' de la brjod par bya/ / 'di ni phyir mi ldog gi gdams ngag go /

Wanting to know in a single thought The signs of cylic births and deaths Of all sentient beings everywhere Do enlightening beings rouse their aspiration.
Wanting to go everywhere unhindered Through physical, verbal, and mental action And comprehend all times are empty and null Do enlightening beings rouse determination.
Having thus determined to become enlightened They should be made to go to all lands To honor and provide for the Enlightened Ones, Whereby to cause them not to regress.
Enlightening beings bravely seeking the Buddha-way Stay in birth and death unwearied For others extolling what will make them follow the way And thus cause them never to regress.
Being honorable leaders in countless lands In the worlds of the ten directions, Teach like this for the enlightening beings Whereby to cause them not to regress.
The supreme, the highest, the foremost, Profound and subtle purest teaching, Urge enlightening beings to teach to people Whereby to cause them to be rid of afflictions.
The unshakable realm of victory, Peerless in all the worlds, Always extols for other enlightening beings To cause them not to regress.
Buddha is the great powerful leader of the world, Replete with all merits and virtues, Causing enlightening beings to abide herein, Thereby teaching them to be superior people.
To countless, boundless Buddhas’ places They can go and draw near, Always taken in to the company of Buddhas, Thus causing them not to regress.
ting 'dzin zhi ba ji snyed gang yod pa/ / de dag gdams ngag ji snyed ma lus par/ / byang chub sems dpa' de la bstan par bya; ; 'di ni phyir mi ldog gi gdams ngag go /

'khor ba'i 'khor lo ldog par 'gyur ba dang / / chos kyi 'khor lo 'khor bar 'gyur ba dang / / 'jig rten kun gyi chags par mi 'gyur ba/ / byang chub sems dpa' de la bstan par bya/ /
sems can sdug bsngal gzir ba ji snyed dang / / ji snyed ngan song gtses par gyur pa yi/ / skyabs dang mgon dang rten du 'gyur bar yang / / byang chub sems dpa' de la brjod par bya/ /
rnam pa 'di 'dras rgyal sras dang po de/ / byang chub don du sems rab skyer 'gyur te/ / de ltar gdams ngag rjes su bstan par bya/ / 'di ni rgyal ba rnams kyi rnam bkod pa 'o/ /
de nas gnyis pa las kyi dang po pa/ / thog ma nyid du sems can thams cad la/ / sems bcu nye bar gzhog cing smon byed pa; ; 'di ni skyon dang bral ba'i gdams ngag go /

To destroy the wheels of birth and death And turn the wheel of the pure wonderous teaching Without attachment to any world: Such is the teaching for enlightening beings.
All sentient beings fall into evil ways Bound and oppressed by measureless pains: To be saviors and reliances for them Is the teaching for enlightening beings.
This is enlightening beings’ abode of initial determination: With single-minded will seeking the unexcelled path; As is the teaching of which I speak, So is the teaching of all the Buddhas.
In the second abode, of preparing the ground, Enlightening beings should form this thought: “All sentient beings everywhere I vow to induce to follow the Buddhas’ teaching.”

phan pa'i sems dang de bzhin bde ba'i sems/ / snying rje'i sems dang de bzhin byams pa'i sems/ / srung ba'i sems dang de bzhin mnyam pa'i sems/ / slob dpon sems dang de bzhin ston pa'i sems/ /
de 'dra'i sems rnams nye bar gzhag pa dang / / kha ton lung la yongs su bskul bar bya/ / mang du thos pa dgon par gnas par bskul/ / dben par gyur pas dge bshes bsnyen bkur bya/ /
dge bshes gyur nas ngang bder 'gyur bar bya; ; ngang tshul bde bas dus tshul shes par bya/ / dus rnams shes nas mi 'jigs 'gyur bar bya/ / mi 'jigs gyur nas don la brtson par bya/ /
don shes gyur nas chos rjes shes par bya/ / chos shes gyur nas rmongs pa med par bya/ / rmongs med gyur nas legs par bshad chos la/ / rgyal sras des ni rnam par gnas par bya/ /
de tsam gyis ni las kyi dang po pa/ / byang chub don zhugs byang chub sems dpa' 'o/ / gdams ngag rjes su bstan pa'ang de yin te/ / sangs rgyas sras po de ltar slob par byed/ /
gang yang byang chub sems dpa' gsum brjod pa/ / chos kyi rgyal po'i gsung la shin tu brtson/ / mi rtag sdug bsngal de bzhin stong pa nyid/ / bdag med de bzhin byed pa med pa dang / /
chos rnams thams cad de bzhin ro med dang / / 'du byed ma yin de bzhin gnas med dang / / ched du spyod med de bzhin rtog med par/ / kun la byang chub sems dpa' dpyod pa byed/ /
de ni 'gro khams yongs su brtag pa dang / / de bzhin chos dbyings brtag par bskul bar bya/ / 'jig rten khams yongs ma lus mthar thug pa/ / brtag par bya la yongs su bskul bar bya/ /
sa dang me dang de bzhin chu khams dang / / de bzhin rlung dang phyogs bcu'i nam mkha' dang / / 'dod pa gzugs dang de bzhin gzugs med pa/ / brtag par bya la yongs su bskul bar bya/ /
khams rnams yangs pa de bzhin kun rtog cing / / khams kyi rang bzhin ma lus mthar phyin pas/ / byang chub sems dpa' rab tu brtson byed pa; ; des na der 'gyur gdams ngag de yin no/ /

With a mind to aid them, with compassion, to give them peace and ease, To establish them securely, with sympathy and acceptance, Protecting sentient beings, looking upon them as the same as themselves, As teachers and as guides— Once abiding in these sublime states of mind Next they are directed to study and learn, To always enjoy peace and quiet and right meditation, And draw near to all good associates.
Speaking gently, with no roughness or harshness, Always speaking appropriately to the situation, without fear, Comprehending the meaning of the teaching and acting in accord, Leaving ignorance and delusion behind, the mind unmoving: This is the practice of beginning study for enlightenment; Those who can do these things are true children of the Buddhas.
I now explain what they should practice; Thus should Buddha-children diligently study: In the third abode of enlightening beings, practice, They should earnestly contemplate, according to Buddha’s teaching, The impermanence, painfulness, and emptiness of all things, The absence of self, person, and activity. All things cannot be enjoyed, None accord with their names, they have no location, There’s nothing of what is conceived, no true reality in them: Those who contemplate thus are called enlightening beings.
Next they are made to observe the realms of sentient beings And urged to contemplate the elemental cosmos: All the various differentiations of the worlds They all should be urged to contemplate and observe.
The worlds of the ten directions, and space, Their earth, water, fire, and air, The realms of desire, form, and formlessness, They are exhorted to investigate thoroughly.
Examining the individual distinctions of those realms, Their substances and natures, exhaustively, Receiving this teaching, diligently cultivating its practice, Is what is called being true Buddha-children.

cher skyes pa yi byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / 'phags pa'i gsung rab 'di las skyes pa ste/ / dngos po rang bzhin med rtogs dran pa can/ / chos kyi rjes byung rigs ldan legs par skyes/ /
de yi gnas las phyir ldog mi 'gyur te/ / sangs rgyas rnams la shin tu mos pa yin/ / chos rnams de bzhin nges par rtogs pa ste/ / sems can rang bzhin med par rnam par bsgoms/ /
chos dang 'jig rten de bzhin zhing rnams dang / / rnam smin 'khor ba de bzhin mya ngan 'das/ / rnam bsgoms rgyal sras de ltar cher skyes pa/ / thugs las byung ba'i sangs rgyas sras zhes bya/ /
'das dang ma byon da ltar byung ba yi/ / sangs rgyas chos rnams rnam par bsgoms pa'i phyir; ; yongs su bsdu ba ci 'dra mthar thug pa/ / de ltar de dag 'grub par 'gyur ba dang / /
sangs rgyas thams cad mnyam pa nyid rtogs shing / / dus gsum mnyam pa nyid kyi rjes song bas/ / mnyam pa nyid la sna tshogs mi dmigs shing / / dus gsum kun la tha dad med par 'jug /
de tsam gyis ni rgyal sras bzhi pa ste; ; de yi bsngags pa rnam pa de 'dra 'o/ / de ltar 'di la nan tan bsgrubs byas shing / / byang chub sems dpa' byang chub mchog tu 'byung / /
de las gzhan yang rgyal sras lnga pa ni; ; sbyor ba phun sum tshogs zhes brjod pa ste/ / thabs mkhas tshul la rjes su zhugs gyur cing / / bsod nams las rnams brtsams pa'i mthar phyin byed/ /
'jig rten dag na bsod nams gang byed kyang / / sems can kun gyi skyabs su 'gyur ba dang / / phan tshol de bzhin bde ba skyed pa dang / / snying brtse skye rgu 'grol bar 'gyur ba dang / /
'jig rten rnams kyi gtse ba bsal ba dang / / dran zhing de bzhin dang bar bya ba dang / / sems can mang po thams cad gdul mos shing / / mya ngan 'das pa'i sems kyi mthu yang che/ /
sems can thams cad kun tu mtha' yas dang / / de bzhin tshad med grangs las 'das pa dang / / bsam gyis mi khyab gzhal med dpag med pa/ / de 'dra'i chos rnams de la brjod par bya/ /
de tsam gyis na rgyal sras lnga pa ste/ / sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa snying rje can/ / de yi gdams ngag tshul ni de 'dra ste/ / yon tan thams cad mnga' bas bstan pa yin; ;

Enlightening beings in the fourth abode, noble birth, Are born from the teachings of the sages; Comprehending that existents have no existence, They transcend things and are born in the realm of reality.
Their faith in Buddha is firm and unbreakable, Their dispassionate mind contemplating things is at peace. Whatever beings there be, they comprehend all Are essentially false, without true reality.
Worlds, lands, actions and rewards, Birth, death, and nirvana are all like this: Buddha-children, contemplating things this way, Are born from Buddha-parents and called Buddha-children.
To know the accumulation and fulfillment Of all the Buddhas’ teachings In past, present, and future worlds, Thus they study, to the ultimate end.
All the enlightened ones of past, present, and future They can contemplate, all equal, In which various distinctions cannot be found: Those who meditate thus comprehend the three time frames.
If any can practice diligently, according to the teaching, The virtues of this fourth abode Such as I am now extolling, They will soon accomplish unsurpassed enlightenment.
From here, enlightening beings of the fifth abode, Called the abode of fulfilling skill in means, Enter deeply into infinite expedient skills, Developing ultimate virtuous action.
The virtues produced by enlightening beings Are all to rescue living beings: Dedicated to aiding and comforting them, They wholeheartedly pity them and liberate them.
Removing difficulties for all beings, Drawing them out of existences, making them happy, They pacify all, leaving none out, Making them all turn to nirvana, full of virtue.
Sentient beings are boundless, Incalculable, countless, inconceivably many, And cannot be told of or measured: Enlightening beings accept this teaching of the Buddha.
These Buddha-children in the fifth abode Develop skillful means to liberate sentient beings; The Saint of Great Knowledge, with all virtues, Enlightens them with teachings like this.

gang yang bsam pa phun sum tshogs bya'i phyir/ / chos kyi ngo bo nyid kyis rmongs med cing / / rnam rtog rtog bral dran dang ldan pa de/ / lhar bcas 'jig rten kun gyis bslu mi nus; ;
sangs rgyas chos dang de bzhin rgyal sras dang / / spyod pas bsngags sam rnam par smad kyang rung / / sems can nyung zhe'am 'on tam mang ngo zhes/ / thos par gyur kyang bsam pa zhum mi 'gyur/ /
sems can nyon mongs nyon mongs med ce'am/ / gdul sla 'on tam shin tu gdul dka' dang / / chos kyi dbyings de chung ngam rgya che dang / / kun nas 'grub 'gyur rnam par 'jig ce 'am/ /
chos dbyings de ni yod dam med ce yang / / byang chub sems dpa' thos gyur dus gsum tshul/ / nges par rtogs byed thams cad rnam rtog cing / / sangs rgyas chos la bsam pa shin tu nges/ /
mtshan ma med dang mtshan nyid med pa dang / / dngos nyid yod min rdzun dang bden pa dang / / sgyu ma rmi lam mi rtog rang bzhin med/ / 'di 'dra'i chos tshol de dag nyan pa byed/ /

In the sixth abode, the fulfillment of right mindfulness, There is no confusion about the inherent nature of things; Meditating with right mindfulness, detaching from discrimination, One cannot be moved by any god or man.
Hearing praise or slander of the Buddhas or their teachings, Of enlightening beings and the practices they perform, Or that sentient beings are finite or infinite, Defiled or undefiled, easy or hard to liberate, Or that the cosmos is great or small, becomes or decays, Or exists or does not, the mind is unmoved: Past, future, and present, Thinking clearly, always sure; All things are signless, Insubstantial, without inherent nature, empty, unreal, Like illusions, like dreams, beyond conception: They always delight in hearing such doctrines.

phyir mi ldog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / sangs rgyas chos dang de bzhin rgyal sras dang / / spyod pa yod med rtag tu rnam par bsgoms/ / 'byung ngam mi 'byung zhe na'ang phyir mi ldog /
de bzhin gshegs pa 'das she'am ma 'das dang / / ma byon to zhe'am ma byon ma yin dang / / skyes so ma skyes zad 'gyur zad mi 'gyur/ / de bzhin mtshan gcig tha dad mtshan de bzhin/ /
gcig pa rnam pa tha dad mang po dang / / don dang de bzhin yi ge'i dngos rnams dang / / thams cad phan tshun yongs su 'dzud byad pa/ / mi ldog byang chub sems dpa' bstan par bya/ /
mtshan ma med la mtshan ma yod pa dang / / mtshan nyid med la mtshan gyis dmigs pa dang / / rnam phye phan tshun yongs su sbyar ba rnams/ / thos nas 'di la mthar thug 'jug pa byed/ /

Enlightening beings of the seventh abode of nonregression Never regress in spite of whatever they hear About Buddhas, the Teaching, or enlightening beings— Whether or not they exist, whether or not they escape, Whether or not there are Buddhas Past, present, and future, Whether Buddha-knowledge is finite or infinite, Whether the past, present, and future are uniform or various. One is many, many are one; Expression follows meaning, meaning follows expression; Thus do all interdependently become: This is what those who don’t regress should explain. Whether things have signs or are signless, Whether they have inherent nature or not; Various distinctions subsume each other: These people, hearing this, attain the ultimate.

gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' gzhon gyur pa/ / lus dang ngag dang de bzhin yid kun gyis/ / kha na ma thor 'gyur pa nam yang med/ / ci 'dod tshul bzhin de ni skye bar byed/ /
gzhan gyi bsam pa ji bzhin rab tu shes/ / de dag mos pa yongs su rtogs par byed/ / phyogs rnams gang du yid kyis smon byed pa/ / kun tu mngon shes myur ba yid bzhin 'thob/ /
bde bar gshegs pas bsngags pa'i chos thos shing / / de la zhum pa skyed pa gang yang med/ / zhing rnams yongs su bskyod pa shes pa dang / / de bzhin byin rlabs rnam par rgyu ba dang / /
sangs rgyas zhing rnams yongs su mnan pa dang / / grangs med kun tu 'gro ba brjod par bya/ / grangs med chos rnams yongs su 'dri ba dang / / ci nas yid kyi rang bzhin lus 'gyur zhing / /
dbyangs kyi rnam pa shin tu yangs 'gyur dang / / sems gcig sangs rgyas grangs med bsnyen bkur brjod/ /

Enlightening beings in the eight abode, youthful nature, Fulfill physical, verbal, and mental actions All pure, without mistakes; They are freely born as they will And know the inclination of sentient beings, Their various understandings, each different, And all the factors involved therein And the signs of becoming and decay of all lands. Attaining to wondrous psychic powers of swiftness, They go anywhere as soon as they think of it: Listening to the teachings from various Buddhas, They praise and practice unflagging. They comprehend all Buddha-lands, Shaking, supporting, and contemplating, Going beyond incalculable buddha-lands, They travel in worlds without number, To ask about innumerable principles; Free to take on any physical form, Their skill in speech pervades everywhere As they serve countless Buddhas.

byang chub sems dpa' rgyal tshab brjod pa ni/ / sems can rnams kyi skye ba rab tu shes; ;
nyon mongs rgyud dang rnam par rgyu ba shes/ / de 'dra'i spyod yul de 'dra'i sbyor ba can/ / chos kyi rgyud mang rnam pa tha dad dang / / sngon mtha' phyi mtha' 'jig rten rnam phye dang / /
brda yi bden pa don dam bden pa dang / / ma lus rtogs par bya ba la mkhas pa yin/ / de yi rgyal po'i gnas la mkhas par bskul/ / der yang ji ltar yongs su spyad bya dang / /
'gro bar bya dang gnas par bya ba dang / / rgyal po'i gnas su ji ltar rnam spyad brjod/ / de la chos kyi rgyal po'i dbang bskur dang / / byin gyis brlabs dang de bzhin mthu chen dang / /
chos su gnas dang 'gro bar bya ba dag / brjod par bya ste rgyal tshab de 'dra yin/ / de tsam gyis na de yi mthar thug ste/ / gdams ngag des kyang rlom sems byed pa med/ /
khong du chud byed dran ldan rgyal tshab de/ / rgyal ba kun gyi drung na slob par byed/ /

Enlightening beings in the ninth abode, of the prince, Can see the difference in births of sentient beings; Knowing their afflictions and habits, They understand which techniques to employ. Individual differences in teachings and in modes of bearing, Dissimilarities of worlds, past and future times, In accord with their conventional and ultimate realities, All they know completely, leaving none out. The skillful set-ups of kings of the teaching, The doctrines they establish according to the situation, The palaces of kings of teaching and their entries As well as what is seen therein, The laws of coronation of the kings of teaching, Their spiritual capacities, empowerments, and fearlessnesses, Their rooms of repose, as well as their praises— With these they instruct the princes of the teaching, Explaining all this for them, exhaustively, And causing their minds to have no attachments; As they comprehend this and cultivate right mindfulness, All the Buddhas appear before them.

bde gshegs sras po gtso bor dbang bskur ba/ / thu bo mchog dang dam par gyur pa ni/ /
'jig rten khams mang grangs med bskyod pa dang / / yongs su snang bar bya ba'i sems kyang mang / / byin gyis brlabs dang yongs su 'da' bya dang / / yongs su sbyangs pa'i sems kyang rab tu mang / /
grangs med 'jig rten shes par bya ba dang / / dbang po phun ldan rnam par dpyad la mkhas/ / de dag gzud cing rnam par gdul ba dang / / thams cad mkhyen gyi sems kyang shin tu mang / /
zhing mang brjod du med par 'gro byas shing / / dam chos khams rnams ma lus rnam par dpyod/ / de yi lus dang lus kyi las rnams dang / / rdzu 'phrul bstan pa'ang shes par mi nus te/ /
dus gsum shin tu rgyal ba'i sems dag kyang / / rgyal tshab gyur pa'i bar gyis shes mi nus/ / de la thams cad gzigs pas dus gsum dang / / sangs rgyas chos shes chags med de bzhin brjod/ /
chos dbyings mtha' yas mtha' dang dbus med pa/ / rgyas par 'gengs par bde gshegs brjod pa mdzad/ / ci nas 'jig rten khams kun ma lus par/ / yongs su snang byed byin gyis rlob pa dang / /
sems can chos rnams de bzhin ma lus dang / / sangs rgyas mtha' yas de bzhin brjod pa'i mdzad/ / rgyal sras brtan pa rnam pa bcur bgrangs pa/ / rnam par dgod la gnas pa de dag kun/ /
rang rang spyod yul rab tu brtson byed pa/ / 'jig rten lhar bcas kun gyis shes par dka'/ / 'on kyang dang por sems bskyed mtha' yas pa/ / phyogs bcu ma lus thams cad rgyas par bya/ /
dus gsum kun tu gang tshe sems gtong ba/ / de tshe thams cad mkhyen pa kun gzigs 'gyur/ /

True Buddha-kings of the tenth abode of coronation Fulfill the unexcelled, foremost teaching. All the countless worlds in the ten directions They can cause to quake, and illumine with their light, Maintaining and traveling to all without exception, Fully purifying and adorning them all. They teach sentient beings without number, Observing and knowing their faculties completely, Inspiring and training boundless beings too, Causing them all to turn to great enlightenment. Observing all phenomenal realms, They travel to all lands in the ten directions: Their embodiments and physical actions there, Their spiritual powers and metamorphoses, are unfathomable. The realms of lands of the Buddhas of all times Even the princes of the teaching cannot understand: The knowledge of all times of the all-seeing, Knowledge understanding all Buddhas’ teachings, Unhindered, boundless knowledge of the realm of realities, Knowledge filling all worlds, Supporting knowledge illumining the world, Knowledge comprehending the states of all beings, And the boundless knowledge of true awakening The Buddhas explain for them, so they will consummate them. Thus the enlightening beings of the ten abodes Are all born by transformation from the teachings of the enlightened; Their practices according to the virtues they have No humans or gods are able to fathom.
In past, future, and present worlds, boundless are those Who set their minds to attain buddhahood; They fill all lands in the ten directions, All determined to become omniscient.

zhing rnams kun la mu mtha' yod ba min/ / sems can chos dang 'jig rten kun de bzhin/ / las dang nyon mongs gnas kyang mtha' yas te/ / byang chub sems rab de la gnas pa yin/ /
skad cig sems la byang chub gzhol ba'i sems/ / gang skyes 'jig rten kun gyis shes mi nus/ / rang rgyal rnams dang nyan thos kun gyis min/ / de nas gong du spyod pa ji skad brjod/ /
gang zhig phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten khams kyi rnams/ / spu gcig srang la tshad du 'jal byed pa/ / des ni byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa shes/ / 'on kyang sangs rgyas ye shes yongs su tshol/ /
phyogs bcu'i rgya mtsho ji snyed yod pa kun/ / spu rtse'i thigs kyis yongs 'jal shes byed pa/ / de ni rgyal sras spyod pa 'di 'dra dag / sems kyi skad cig gcig la sgrub par byed/ /
ji ltar zhing rnams rdul rab phrar glags shing / / sems can la la ma lus bgrang byed de/ / 'di snyed yod ces grangs su gcod byed pa/ / de 'drar rgyal sras spyod pa brjod pa'o/ /
'das pa'i sangs rgyas de bzhin ma byon dang / / gang rnams phyogs bcur byung bar gyur pa dang / / rang rgyal de bzhin nyan thos rab mang bar/ / rnam par dmigs shing byang chub sems skye'o/ /
sems can khams rnams ma lus rgyas bkang zhing / / byang chub don du thog mar sems bskyed pa/ / de yang bgrang bar nus pa ma yin na/ / de las gong du ci zhig smos kyang dgos/ /

Boundless is the totality of all lands; Boundless too are the states of worlds and beings, Their delusions, actions, and inclinations each different: Due to them enlightening beings aspire to enlightenment.
The very first thought to seek buddhahood Worldlings, or even those Of the two vehicles cannot know— Much less the other virtuous practices.
If one can lift with a single hair All the worlds in the ten directions, One can know these Buddha-children’s Progression toward the wisdom of the enlightened ones.
If one can drain by drops with a hair The waters of all oceans in the ten directions, One can know the virtuous deeds Practiced by these Buddha-children in a single instant.
If one can reduce all worlds to dust And know the specific number of each mote, Such a person alone can see The path traversed by these Buddha-children.
The Buddhas of all places and times, All self-enlightened ones and Buddhas’ disciples, All with various powers of elucidation Illustrate the mind first bent on enlightenment.
The virtues of this aspiration cannot be measured: If all the knowledges filling all realms of beings Were to explain together, they could not exhaust it, Much less the rest of the wondrous practices carried out.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ byang chub sems dpa'i rnam par dgod pa bcu bstan pa'i le'u ste; nyi shu pa'o// //
[21. tshangs par spyod pa'i le'u]
BOOK SIXTEEN. Religious Practice
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba/ bam po nyi shu gnyis pa/

de nas lha'i bu dran pa dang ldan pas byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na byang chub sems dpa' 'phags pa'i gsung rab la khyim nas khyim med par rab tu byung zhing ngur smrig gi gos 'chang ba de dag gis tshangs pa'i spyod pa yongs su dag pa gang gis byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dgod pa 'di dag las 'das te myur du bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'byung bar 'gyur ba de ji ltar yid la bya/ de skad ces smras pa dang;

THEN THE GODLING Right Mindfulness said to the enlightening being Truth Wisdom, “In all worlds, enlightening beings, following the teaching of the Enlightened Ones, dye their clothing and leave home to become mendicants: how can they attain purity of religious practice, and from the state of enlightening reach the path of unexcelled enlightenment?”

byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyis lha'i bu dran pa dang ldan pa la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bas na; byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa la yang dag par zhugs pa rnams kyis dmigs pa bcu rnam par bsgoms te gong du chos bcu yid la bya'o/ / dmigs pa bcu rnam par bsgoms pa gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ lus dang lus kyi las dang / ngag dang ngag kyi las dang / yid dang yid kyi las dang / sangs rgyas dang / chos dang / dge 'dun dang / bslab pa yang dag par blang ba dag ste/ ci/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa de lus sam/ de ste tshangs pa'i spyod pa de lus yin na ni/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa mi gtsang bar 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa chos ma yin par 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa 'khrugs par 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa dri nga bar 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa gtsang ba ma yin par 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa smad par 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa mi mthun par 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa keng rus su 'gyur/ tshangs pa'i spyod pa srin gyi tshang du 'gyur ro/ / de ste lus kyi las tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ nyal ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ 'dug pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ 'greng ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ 'gro ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ bltas pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rnam par bltas pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ bskum pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ brkyang ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ 'khor ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ 'gres pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur ro/ / de ste ngag tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ dbyangs tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ nga ro tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ brjod pa tshangs pa'i spyod bar 'gyur/ smra ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ smros pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur; thong gnas rtsol ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ lce bsgyur ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ mchu sbyar ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ tshig sbyar ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur ro/ / de ste ngag gi las tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ / brjod pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ brdar byas pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ shin tu bstan pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ bstan pas rnam par bstan pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ legs par brjod pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ ngan du brjod pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rnam par gdags pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rnam par spyod pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ yongs su smos pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur ro/ / de ste yid tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ dpyod pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rnam par dpyod pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rtog pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rnam par rtog pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ dran pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ phyir dran pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ sems pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rnam par sems pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ sgyu ma tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ rmi lam tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur ro/ / de ste yid kyi las tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ 'du shes tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ yid la byed pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ grang ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ dro ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ bde ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur; sdug bsngal tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ bkres pa changs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ skom pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ dga' ba tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur/ zhum pa tshangs pa'i spyod par 'gyur ro/ / de ste sangs rgyas tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ gzugs sangs rgyas sam/ 'on tam tshor ba sangs rgyas sam; 'du shes sangs rgyas sam/ 'du byed sangs rgyas sam/ rnam par shes pa sangs rgyas sam/ mtshan rnams sangs rgyas sam/ mngon par shes pa sangs rgyas sam/ las sangs rgyas sam/ 'on te rnam par smin pa sangs rgyas sam/ de ste legs par bshad pa'i chos nyid tshangs par spyod pa'i gnas yin na ni/ 'gog pa gnas su 'gyur ro/ / mya ngan las 'das pa gnas su 'gyur ro/ / bral ba gnas su 'gyur ro/ / ma skyes pa gnas su 'gyur ro/ / ma byung ba gnas su 'gyur ro// grags pa med pa gnas su 'gyur ro/ / rtog pa med pa gnas su 'gyur ro/ / rgyu ba med pa gnas su 'gyur ro/ / phrad pa med pa'i gnas ni/ tshangs pa'i gnas su 'gyur ro/ / de ste dge 'dun sdom pa'i nan tan can tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu'i phyir dge 'dun nam/ 'on tam rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu dge 'dun/ lan gcig phyir 'ong ba'i 'bras bu'i phyir dge 'dun nam/ 'on tam lan gcig phyir 'od ba'i 'bras bu dge 'dun/ phyir mi 'ong ba'i 'bras bu'i phyir dge 'dun nam/ 'on tam phyir mi 'ong ba'i 'bras bu dge 'dun/ dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu'i phyir dge 'dun nam/ 'on tam dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu dge 'dun/ gsum rig pa nyid dge 'dun nam/ drug mngon par shes pa dge 'dun nam/ 'on tam khong du chud par nan tan du byed pa tshangs pa'i spyod pa/ de ste bslab pa yang dag par blangs pa tshangs pa'i spyod pa yin na ni/ tha dad du gnas pa bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/ yongs su dag pa bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/ slob dpon gyi tshig bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/ lan gsum du bzlas pa bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/ mkhan po bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/ skra bregs pa dang / ngur smrig gi gos 'chang ba bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/ slong mos 'tsho ba bslab pa yang dag par blang ba'am/

Truth Wisdom said, “Great enlightening beings, when performing religious practice, should attentively contemplate ten things objectively: the body, physical action, speech, verbal action, mind, mental action, Buddha, the Teaching, the religious community, and the precepts. They should contemplate in this way: Is the body religious practice? And so on, down to: Are precepts religious practice? If the body were religious practice, then religious practice would be not good, it would not be the true teaching, it would be defiled, it would be impure, it would be foul, it would be unclean, it would be disgusting, it would be intractable, it would be defined, it would be a corpse, it would be a mass of microbes. If physical action were religious practice, then religious practice would be walking, standing, sitting, lying down, looking around, up and down. If speech were religious practice, then religious practice would be sound and breath, chest, tongue, lips, exhalation and inhalation, constriction and relaxation, high and low, clear and unclear. If verbal activity were religious practice, then religious practice would be greetings, summary explanations, extensive explanations, metaphorical explanations, direct explanations, praise, criticism, definitions, explanations accommodated to conventions, clear explanations. If the mind were religious practice, then religious practice would be consideration and pondering, discrimination, various discriminations, conception, various conceptions, thought, various thoughts, acts of illusion and dreams. If mental activity were religious practice, then religious practice would be ideas, cold and heat, hunger and thirst, pain and pleasure, sorrow and joy. If Buddha is religious practice, is material form to be considered Buddha? Is sensation Buddha? Is conception Buddha? Is action Buddha? Are spiritual powers Buddha? Are works Buddha? Are resulting consequences Buddha? If the Teaching is religious practice, is extinction the Teaching? Is nirvana the Teaching? Is nonbirth the Teaching? Is nonorigination the Teaching? Is inexplicability the Teaching? Is nondiscrimination the Teaching? Is nonaction the Teaching? Is nonconjunction the Teaching? If the Community is religious practice, is heading for stream-entering the Community? Is the fruit of stream-entering the Community? Is heading for the state of once-returner the Community? Is the fruit of once-returner the Community? Is heading for the state of nonreturner the Community? Is the fruit of nonreturner the Community? Is heading for sainthood the Community? Is the fruit of sainthood the Community? Are those with the three super-knowledges the Community? Are those with the six paranormal powers the Community? If the precepts are religious practice, is the ordination altar the precepts? Is asking about purity the precepts? Is teaching proper manners the precepts? Is the threefold repetition the precepts? Is the instructor the precepts? Is the tutor the precepts? Is shaving off the hair the precepts? Is putting on the monastic garb the precepts? Is begging the precepts? Is right livelihood the precepts?

'on tam de dag tshangs pa'i spyod pa'am zhes de ltar chos de dag la rnam par sgom na/ bdag gi lus la mngon par chags pa med pa dang / sgom pa la zhen pa med pa dang / chos rnams gnas pa med pa dang / 'das pa rgyu ba med pa dang / ma 'ongs pa ma phyin pa dang / da ltar byung ba stong pa dang / las la byed pa med pa dang / rnam par smin pa la tshor ba med pa dang / 'jig rten 'di 'phos pa med pa dang / 'jig rten pha rol chud mi za ba'i phyir tshangs pa'i spyod pa zhes bya ba'i chos de gang yin/ de gang las byung / de su'i/ de ci zhig/ de sus byas/ de yod dam/ de med dam/ de gzugs sam/ de gzugs ma yin nam/ de tshor ba'am/ de tshor ba ma yin nam; de 'du shes sam/ de 'du shes ma yin nam/ de 'du byed dam/ de 'du byed ma yin nam/ de rnam par shes pa'am/ de rnam par shes pa ma yin nam/ tshangs par spyod pa'i chos de gang zhig ces de ltar mi dmigs shing dus gsum mnyam pa nyid du nam mkha' yongs su rgyas par bya ba dang / chags pa med par yid la bya ba dang / sems la bsgribs pa med pa dang / gnyis su med par shin tu spyod pa dang / bsgribs pa med pa'i sbyor ba dang / mtshan ma med pa'i chos gzung ba dang / mtshan nyid med pa'i chos rab tu shes pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos mnyam pa nyid dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la yang dag par sems pas tshangs pa'i spyod pa yongs su dag par yid la bya'o/ /

“Having contemplated thus, having no attachment to the body, no clinging to practice, no dwelling on doctrine, the past gone, the future not yet arrived, the present empty, there is no doer, no receiver of consequences; this time doesn’t move, another time doesn’t shift—what thing is therein to be called religious practice? Where does religious practice come from? Where is it? Who is the body? By whom is it performed? Does it exist? Does it not exist? Is it form? Is it not form? Is it sensation? Is it not sensation? Is it conception? Is it not conception? Is it action? Is it not action? Is it consciousness? Is it not consciousness? Contemplating in this way, because the reality of religious practice cannot be apprehended, because the things of past, present, and future are all empty, because the intellect has no attachment, because the mind has no obstruction, because the sphere of operation is nondual, because expedient means are free, because of acceptance of formless truth, because of contemplation of formless truth, because of knowing the Buddha’s teaching is equanimous, because of fulfilling all qualities of Buddhahood, is such practice called pure religious practice.

gong du yang chos bcu dang ldan pas yid la bya ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ gnas dang gnas ma yin pa shes pa dang / 'das pa dang / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i las dang / rnam par smin pa shes pa dang ldan pa dang / bsam gtan dang / rnam par thar pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / snyoms par 'jug pa dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa dang / rnam par byang ba dang / rnam par ldang ba shes pa dang ldan pa dang / dbang po dang / brtson 'grus tha dad pa dang / yongs su rdzogs pa mchog dang / tha ma shes pa dang ldan pa dang / mos pa tha dad pa dang / mos pa du ma shes pa dang ldan pa dang / khams tha dad pa dang / khams du ma shes pa dang ldan pa dang / thams cad du 'gro ba'i lam shes pa dang ldan pa dang / lha'i mig thogs pa med pa dang ldan pa dang / bsgribs pa med pa rjes su dran pa shes pa dang ldan pa dang / bag chags kyi mtshams sbyor ba yang dag par gcad pa shes pa dang ldan pa ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i stobs re re la yang rnam par dbye ba shin tu rgya che bar khong du chud par bya'o/ / thams cad kyang tshad med par blta bar bya'o/ / thos nas kyang snying rje chen po la bstan par bya'o/ / sems can rnam par sgom pa yang mi gtang bar bya'o/ / chos la shin tu brtag pa yang mi gzhig par bya'o/ / bla na med pa'i chos la yang dag pa'i yi dam yang shin tu brtsam par bya'o/ / rnam par smin pa la yang re ba med par bya'o/ / sgyu ma'i rang bzhin yang rjes su rtogs par bya'o/ / rmi lam gyi rang bzhin du yang yang dag par spyad par bya'o/ / mig yor gyi rang bzhin dang yang tha mi dad par bya'o/ / sgra brnyan gyi rang bzhin yang spyod yul du bya'o/ / sprul pa'i rang bzhin du yang mos par bya ste/ de de ltar zhugs pas nyon mongs pa chung bar sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyang mngon du 'gyur ro/ / des chos de dag gnyis su med par rtogs pas sems dang po bskyed pa nyid kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya ba'i gnas yod do/ chos thams cad sems kyi rang bzhin du shes pas gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog par shes rab kyi phung po dang yang ldan par 'gyur ro/ /

“Ten things should also be cultivated: knowledge of what is so and what is not; knowledge of past, present, and future consequences of actions; knowledge of all meditations, liberations, and concentrations; knowledge of superiority and inferiority of faculties; knowledge of all kinds of understandings; knowledge of all kinds of realms; knowledge of where all paths lead; unhindered clairvoyance; unhindered knowledge of past lives; knowledge of the eternal cancellation of habit energy. Contemplating each of these ten powers of the enlightened, in each power are innumerable meanings; one should ask about them, and after having heard about them should arouse a mind of great kindness and compassion and observe sentient beings without abandoning them, reflect on the teachings unceasingly, carry out superlative deeds without seeking rewards, comprehend that objects are like dreams, like illusions, like reflections, like echoes, and like magical productions. If enlightening beings can unite with such contemplations, they will not entertain a dualistic understanding of things and all enlightening teachings will become evident to them: at the time of their first determination they will immediately attain complete perfect enlightenment, will know all things are the mind’s own nature, and will perfect the body of wisdom and understand without relying on another.”

BOOK SEVENTEEN. The Merit of The Initial Determination for Enlightenment

de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bsod nams kyi phung po ji tsam zhig dang ldan na/ sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dbar 'gyur/ de skad ces smras pa dang /
THEN INDRA, king of gods, said to the enlightening being Truth Wisdom, “Son of Buddha, what is the extent of the merit attained when the enlightening being first determines to become enlightened?”

byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros kyis lha'i dbang po brgya byin la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gnas 'di ni/ yid ches par shin tu dka' ste/ shes par dka'/ brtag par dka'/ mngon par dad par dka'/ shin tu rtogs par dka'/ kun nas sgrub par dka'/ yang dag par spyad par dka'/ brjod par dka'/ bskyed par dka'/ brgal bar dka'/ khong du chud par dka'/ 'on kyang ci tshul du sangs rgyas kyi mthus bshad par bya'o/ /

Truth Wisdom said, “The truth of this is extremely deep, difficult to explain, difficult to know, difficult to discern, difficult to believe, difficult to experience, difficult to practice, difficult to master, difficult to think of, difficult to assess, difficult to approach and enter. Even so, by the power of the Buddha I will explain for you.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de la ji snyam du sems/ gang shar phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par gtogs pa'i sems can de dag la la zhig gis bskal par bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te bslab pa'i tshig lnga po dag kyang 'dzin du btsud par gyur la/ de bzhin du lho phyogs dang / nub phyogs dang / byang phyogs dang / de bzhin du byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams dang / shar lho'i phyogs mtshams dang / lho nub kyi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du nub byang gi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du 'og gi phyogs dang / de bzhin du steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par gtogs pa'i sems can rnams kyang bskal par bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te bslab pa'i tshig lnga po dag kyang 'dzin du btsud na/ rgyal ba'i sras/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i rgyus bsod nams mang du 'phel lam/ de skad ces smras pa dang /

“O Child of Buddha, suppose someone were to provide all comforts for all the beings of incalculable worlds in the eastern direction for a whole eon, and after that teach them to keep the five precepts with purity, and were to do the same thing in the southern, western, and northern directions, the four intermediate directions, and the zenith and nadir as well — do you think this person’s merit would be much?”

lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi blo gros la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bsod nams 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ma gtogs par gzhan gyis shes par mi nus so/ / smras pa/
Indra said, “Only a Buddha could know this person’s merit — no one else could be able to assess it.”

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sems dang po bskyed pa'i bsod nams kyi phung po la ni; de dag gi bsod nams snga ma des brgya'i char yang nye bar mi 'gro/ stong gi char yang nye bar mi 'gro /brgya stong gi cha dang / bye ba'i cha dang / bye ba brgya'i cha dang / bye ba stong gi cha dang / bye ba brgya stong gi cha dang / bye ba khrag khrig brgya'i cha dang / bye ba khrag khrig stong gi cha dang / bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong gi char yang nye bar mi 'gro/ grangs dang / cha dang / bgrang ba dang / dpe dang / rgyur yang nye bar mi 'gro'o/ /

Truth Wisdom said, “This person’s merit, compared to the merit of an enlightening being who has just determined to realize enlightenment, does not amount even to a hundredth, not even a thousandth, a hundred thousandth, a millionth, a hundred millionth, a billionth, a hundred billionth, a trillionth, a hundred trillionth, a quadrillionth, a quintillionth—that merit does not amount to the smallest imaginable fraction of the merit of determination for enlightenment.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ dpe snga ma dag lta zhog gi/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par gtogs pa'i sems can ji snyed pa de dag bskal pa brgyar bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam rnams la yang dag par sbyar bar gyur la/ gzhung de bzhin du bskal pa stong du bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te bsam gtan bzhi la rab tu bkod pa dang / bskal pa brgya phrag stong du bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te tshangs pa'i rnam par spyod pa bzhi la rab tu bkod pa dang / bskal pa bye bar bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa bzhi la rab tu bkod par gyur pa dang / bskal pa bye bar bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu la rab tu bkod pa dang / bskal pa bye ba stong du bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te lan gcig phyir 'ong ba'i 'bras bu la rab tu bkod pa dang / bskal pa bya ba brgya stong du bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te phyir mi 'ong ba'i 'bras bu la rab tu bkod pa dang / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig tu bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te dgra bcom pa la rab tu bkod pa dang / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis rim gror byas te rang sangs rgyas kyi byang chub la rab tu bzhag par gyur na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de'i rgyus bsod nams mang du 'phel lam/

“Setting aside that example for the moment, suppose someone provided all the beings of ten infinities of worlds with medicines for a hundred eons, and then taught them to practice the path of ten virtues, serving them thus for a thousand eons; then teaching them to dwell in the four meditations for a hundred thousand eons, then teaching them to dwell in the four immeasurable states of mind for a hundred million eons, then teaching them to dwell in the four formless concentrations for ten billion eons, then teaching them to dwell in the state of stream-enterer for a hundred billion eons, then teaching them to dwell in the state of once-returner for ten trillion eons, then teaching them to dwell in the state of nonreturner for a quadrillion eons, then teaching them to dwell in sainthood for a quintillion eons, then teaching them to dwell in the path of the self-enlightened; do you think this person’s merit would be great?”
lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis mkhyen to/ /
The king of gods said, “Only a Buddha could know the merit of such a person.”

/ bgrang ba dang / dpe dang / rgyur yang nye bar mi 'gro'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gang 'di phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par gtogs pa'i sems can bskal pa bye ba sems skye'o/ / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad 'du ba dang / 'jig pa yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gtogs pa'i sems can rnams kyi kun nas nyon mongs pa dang / rnam par byang ba yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rang bzhin yongs su dag pa yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ / sems can thams cad sems skye'o/ / sems can thams cad kyi dbang po dang / sbyor ba yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ / sems can thams cad kyi sems dang / spyod pa yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ / sems can thams cad kyi dus gsum gyi shes pa yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi sems bskyed pa de ni/ 'di ltar sangs rgyas thams cad dang yul mnyam pa nyid du bya ba'i phyir sems skye'o/ /

Truth Wisdom said, “This person’s merit, compared to the merit of an enlightening being who has just determined to realize enlightenment, does not amount to a hundredth part, not even a thousandth, a hundred thousandth, or even the smallest imaginable fraction thereof. Why? Because when the Buddhas first set their minds on enlightenment, they do not do so just to provide the beings of innumerable worlds in all directions with all comforts for a hundred eons or a hundred thousand quadrillion eons. They do not set their minds on enlightenment just to teach that many beings to cultivate morality and goodness, just to teach them to abide in the four meditations, four immeasurable minds, and four formless concentrations, just to teach them to attain the states of stream-enterer, once-returner, nonreturner, saint, and independently enlightened one. Rather, they set their minds on enlightenment to cause the lineage of the enlightened ones not to die out, to pervade all worlds, to liberate the sentient beings of all worlds, to know the formation and disintegration of all worlds, to know the defilement and purity of beings in all worlds, to know the inherent purity of all worlds, to know the inclinations, afflictions, and mental habits of all sentient beings, to know where all sentient beings die and are born, to know expedient means appropriate to the faculties of all sentient beings, to know the mentalities of all sentient beings, to know all sentient beings’ knowledge of past, present, and future, and to know all realms of Buddhas are equal.

gcig 'jig rten gyi khams brjod du med par gzud pa yongs su shes pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams kun nas nyon mongs pa 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par dag par yongs su shes pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams 'jig rten gyi khams 'byams klas pa ma lus pa thams cad sems bskyed pa gcig gis thogs pa med par yongs su shes pas/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi sems bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu skye'o/ /

“Again, setting this example aside for the moment, suppose someone could, in a single instant, pass incalculably many worlds to the east, and did this instant after instant for an incalculable eon—no one could determine a limit to those worlds. Then suppose there were another person who could pass in a single instant all the worlds that the former person passed in an incalculable eon, and also went on thus for an incalculable eon. Then suppose there were yet another person, and another and another, up to ten, each of whom could pass in an instant all the worlds that the preceding one passed in an incalculable eon, and went on thus for an incalculable eon. Then suppose there were also such people in all the other nine directions. Thus in the ten directions there would be one hundred people, each successively passing in each and every instant of an eon as many worlds as the preceding passed in an eon: the limit of these worlds might be known, but the limit of the roots of goodness in the enlightening being’s initial determination on enlightenment cannot be known. Why? Because enlightening beings do not set their minds on enlightenment just to go to and gain knowledge of a limited number of worlds; they set their minds on enlightenment to know all worlds in the ten directions. That is to say, they want to know subtle worlds are gross worlds, gross worlds are subtle worlds, upward facing worlds are downward facing worlds, downward facing worlds are upward facing worlds, small worlds are large worlds, large worlds are small worlds, wide worlds are narrow worlds, narrow worlds are wide worlds, one world is unspeakably many worlds, unspeakably many worlds are one world, one world enters unspeakably many worlds, unspeakably many worlds enter one world, defiled worlds are pure worlds, pure worlds are defiled worlds; they want to know the differentiations of all worlds in a single hair, and the unity of a single hair in all worlds. They want to know the production of all worlds in a single world. They want to know the insubstantiality of all worlds. They want to be able to know all vast worlds in a single moment of thought without any hindrance. This is why they set their minds on unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment.

pa sangs rgyas brjod du med pa'i bskal par yang dag par 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / 'di lta ste/ bskal pa rnam pa tha dad pa la bskal pa rnam pa tha mi dad par yang dag par 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / bskal pa rnam pa tha mi dad pa la bskal pa rnam pa tha dad par yang dag par 'jug pa shes pa dang / bskal pa zad pa la bskal pa ma zad par yang dag par 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / bskal pa ma zad pa la bskal pa zad par khong du chud pas yang dag par 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / 'di lta ste/ bskal pa brjod du med pa sems bskyed pa gcig tu yang dag par 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / sems bskyed pa gcig bskal pa brjod du med par yang dag par 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / 'di lta ste/ bskal pa thams cad bskal pa med par rab tu 'jug pa shes par bya ba dang / bskal pa ma yin pa bskal par 'jug pa shes par bya ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems skye'o/ / 'di lta ste/ sngon gyi mtha'i mur thug pa'i bskal pa dang / phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i bskal pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i bskal pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad kyi 'du ba dang / 'jig pa'i bskal pa sems bskyed pa gcig gis yongs su shes par bya ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas su sems skye ste/ 'di ltar bskal pa thams cad kyi rgyus mngon par shes par bya ba'i phyir de thog mar go cha chen po mngon par sgrub bo/ /

“Again, setting this example aside, suppose there is someone who can in a single thought know the number of eons of becoming and decay of innumerable worlds in the eastern direction, and does this for an incalculable eon; no one can determine the bounds of those numbers of eons. Then suppose there is a second person who can know in a single thought all the numbers of eons known by the first person over an incalculable eon. Again, continue this up to ten persons, then extend it to all ten directions. The limit of the number of eons of becoming and decay of all these incalculable worlds of the ten directions may be known, but the limit of the virtues of the enlightening being setting the mind on perfect enlightenment cannot be known. Why? Because enlightening beings do not set the mind on unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment just to know the number of eons of becoming and decay of a certain limited number of worlds. It is to completely know the eons of becoming and decay of all worlds that they set their minds on unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment. That is, to know that long eons and short eons are equal; short eons and long eons are equal; one eon is equal to countless eons; countless eons are equal to one eon; eons with Buddhas are equal to eons without Buddhas; eons without Buddhas are equal to eons with Buddhas; in an eon with one Buddha there are unspeakably many Buddhas; in an eon with unspeakably many Buddhas there is one Buddha; finite eons are equal to infinite eons; infinite eons are equal to finite eons; eons that end are equal to endless eons; endless eons are equal to eons that end; unspeakably many eons are equal to one instant; one instant is equal to unspeakably many eons; all eons enter the noneon; the noneon enters all eons. [1. That is, “eon” is a division that is ultimately arbitrary.] They want to know instantly the eons of becoming and decay of all worlds of the entire past, present, and future—that is why they set their minds on unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment. This is called the initial determination’s adornment of great vows, the spiritual knowledge of all eons.

kye rgyal ba'i sras; 'jig rten gyi khams 'du ba dang / 'jig pa'i bskal pa bgrang ba'i dpe de dag lta zhog gi /kye rgyal ba'i sras/ 'di la skyes bu la la zhig skyes par gyur te/ des sems bskyed pa gcig gis 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par gtogs pa'i sems can rnams kyi dad pa sna tshogs pa thams cad shes la/ tshul de lta bur sems bskyed pa re re zhing shes pas shar phyogs su bskal pa grangs med pa zad par byas kyang sems can rnams kyi mos pa tha dad pa gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa'i mtha' zad par mi rung ba nas gzhung de bzhin du skyes bu bcu pa'i bar du ste/ shar phyogs su ji lta ba de bzhin du steng gi phyogs kyi bar gyi phyogs bcu thams cad du rgya cher byas na/ de dag gi mos pa tha dad pa gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa ni/ mthar thug par rung yang srid kyi/ byang chub sems dpa' bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems dang po bskyed pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba ni/ mthar thug par mi rung ngo/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ sems can de tsam gyi mos pa tha dad pa shes par bya ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems mi skye'i/ 'di ltar 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du gtogs pa'i sems can rnams kyi dad pa sna tshogs mngon par 'tshang rgya bar bya ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' rnams bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems skye'o/ / 'di lta ste; mos pa mtha' dang dbus med
